It thus has no effect on photosynthesising plants.{{cite web|url=http://ces.iisc.ernet.in/energy/HC270799/HDL/ENV/enven/vol321.htm|title=Carbon monoxide|work=ernet.in|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140414051805/http://ces.iisc.ernet.in/energy/HC270799/HDL/ENV/enven/vol321.htm|archivedate=2014-04-14|df=}} It is easily absorbed through the lungs. Inhaling the gas can lead to [[Cerebral hypoxia|hypoxic injury]], [[Brain damage|nervous system damage]], and even [[death]]. Different people and populations may have different carbon monoxide tolerance levels.{{cite journal|vauthors=Raub JA, Mathieu-Nolf M, Hampson NB, Thom SR |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning-a public health perspective|journal=Toxicology|date=April 2000|pages=1–14|volume=145|issue=1|pmid=10771127|doi=10.1016/S0300-483X(99)00217-6|subscription=yes}} On average, exposures at 100 [[parts per million|ppm]] or greater is dangerous to human health. In the [[United States]], the [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]] limits long-term workplace exposure levels to less than 50 ppm averaged over an 8-hour period;{{cite web|url=https://www.osha.gov/OshDoc/data_General_Facts/carbonmonoxide-factsheet.pdf|title=OSHA Fact Sheet: Carbon Monoxide|accessdate=2009-09-14|publisher=United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826181843/http://osha.gov/OshDoc/data_General_Facts/carbonmonoxide-factsheet.pdf|archivedate=2009-08-26|df=}} in addition, employees are to be removed from any [[confined space]] if an upper limit ("ceiling") of 100 ppm is reached.{{cite web |url=https://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_table=STANDARDS&p_id=10366 |title=Carbon monoxide – 29 CFR Part 1917 Section 1917.24 |accessdate=2013-05-27 |publisher=United States Department of Labor: Occupational Safety and Health Administration |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523211713/http://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_table=STANDARDS&p_id=10366 |archivedate=2013-05-23 |df= }} Carbon monoxide exposure may lead to a significantly shorter [[life expectancy|life span]] due to [[heart]] damage.{{cite journal|vauthors=Henry CR, Satran D, Lindgren B, Adkinson C, Nicholson CI, Henry TD |title= Myocardial Injury and Long-term Mortality Following Moderate to Severe Carbon Monoxide Poisoning|journal=JAMA|date=January 2006|volume=295|pages=398–402|doi= 10.1001/jama.295.4.398|pmid=16434630|issue= 4|url= http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=16434630|format= Free full text}} The carbon monoxide tolerance level for any person is altered by several factors, including activity level, [[Ventilation (physiology)|rate of ventilation]], a pre-existing [[Cerebrum|cerebral]] or [[cardiovascular disease]], [[cardiac output]], [[anemia]], [[sickle cell disease]] and other hematological disorders, [[barometric pressure]], and [[metabolic rate]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lungusa.org/site/pp.asp?c=dvLUK9O0E&b=35375|title=Carbon Monoxide|accessdate=2009-09-14|publisher=American Lung Association|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080528195959/http://www.lungusa.org/site/pp.asp?c=dvLUK9O0E&b=35375 |archivedate =2008-05-28|deadurl=yes}}{{cite journal|author=Lipman GS|title=Carbon monoxide toxicity at high altitude|journal=Wilderness & Environmental Medicine|year=2006|pages=144–45|volume=17|issue=2|pmid=16805152|doi=10.1580/1080-6032(2006)17[144:CMTAHA]2.0.CO;2}}{{cite book|author=first draft prepared by Mr J. Raub.|title=Environmental Health Criteria 213 (Carbon Monoxide)|publisher=International Programme on Chemical Safety, World Health Organization|location=Geneva|year=1999|pages=|isbn=9241572132}} {| class="wikitable" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; border: none;" |+Effects of carbon monoxide in relation to the concentration in parts per million in the air:{{cite journal|author=Goldstein M|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Journal of Emergency Nursing|volume=34|issue=6|pages=538–42|date=December 2008|pmid=19022078|doi=10.1016/j.jen.2007.11.014}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Struttmann T, Scheerer A, Prince TS, Goldstein LA |title=Unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning from an unlikely source|journal=The Journal of the American Board of Family Practice|volume=11|issue=6|pages=481–84|date=Nov 1998|pmid=9876005|doi=10.3122/jabfm.11.6.481}} !Concentration !Symptoms |- |35 ppm (0.0035%) |Headache and dizziness within six to eight hours of constant exposure |- |100 ppm (0.01%) |Slight headache in two to three hours |- |200 ppm (0.02%) |Slight headache within two to three hours; loss of judgment |- |400 ppm (0.04%) |Frontal headache within one to two hours |- |800 ppm (0.08%) | Dizziness, nausea, and convulsions within 45 min; insensible within 2 hours |- |1,600 ppm (0.16%) |Headache, [[tachycardia|increased heart rate]], dizziness, and nausea within 20 min; death in less than 2 hours |- |3,200 ppm (0.32%) |Headache, dizziness and nausea in five to ten minutes. Death within 30 minutes. |- |6,400 ppm (0.64%) |Headache and dizziness in one to two minutes. Convulsions, respiratory arrest, and death in less than 20 minutes. |- |12,800 ppm (1.28%) |Unconsciousness after 2–3 breaths. Death in less than three minutes. |- |} === Acute poisoning === [[File:CO toxicity symptoms (en).jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|CO toxicity symptoms]] The main manifestations of carbon monoxide poisoning develop in the organ systems most dependent on oxygen use, the [[central nervous system]] and the [[heart]]. The initial symptoms of acute carbon monoxide poisoning include [[headache]], [[nausea]], [[malaise]], and [[fatigue (medical)|fatigue]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Hardy KR, Thom SR |title=Pathophysiology and treatment of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Journal of Toxicology. Clinical Toxicology|year=1994|pages=613–29|volume=32|issue=6|pmid=7966524|doi=10.3109/15563659409017973}} These symptoms are often mistaken for a virus such as [[influenza]] or other illnesses such as [[food poisoning]] or [[gastroenteritis]].{{cite book |title=Goldfrank's toxicologic emergencies |publisher=McGraw-Hill |location=New York |year=2002 |edition=7th |pages=1689–1704 |chapter=Carbon Monoxide |isbn=0071360018 |author1=Lewis Goldfrank |author2=Neal Flomenbaum |author3=Neal Lewin |author4=Mary Ann Howland |author5=Robert Hoffman |author6=Lewis Nelson}} Headache is the most common symptom of acute carbon monoxide poisoning; it is often described as dull, frontal, and continuous.{{cite journal|vauthors=Hampson NB, Hampson LA |title=Characteristics of headache associated with acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Headache|volume=42|issue=3|pages=220–23|date=March 2002|pmid=11903546|doi=10.1046/j.1526-4610.2002.02055.x}} Increasing exposure produces cardiac abnormalities including [[tachycardia|fast heart rate]], [[hypotension|low blood pressure]], and [[cardiac arrhythmia]];{{cite journal |vauthors=Tritapepe L, Macchiarelli G, Rocco M, Scopinaro F, Schillaci O, Martuscelli E, Motta PM |title=Functional and ultrastructural evidence of myocardial stunning after acute carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=Critical Care Medicine |volume=26 |issue=4 |pages=797–801 |date=April 1998 |pmid=9559621 |doi=10.1097/00003246-199804000-00034}} [[central nervous system]] symptoms include [[delirium]], [[hallucination]]s, [[dizziness]], [[ataxia|unsteady gait]], [[confusion]], [[seizures]], [[central nervous system depression]], [[unconsciousness]], [[respiratory arrest]], and [[death]].{{cite journal|author=Weaver LK|title=Clinical practice. Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=360|issue=12|pages=1217–25|date=March 2009|pmid=19297574|doi=10.1056/NEJMcp0808891|url=http://content.nejm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=short&pmid=19297574&promo=ONFLNS19}} Less common symptoms of acute carbon monoxide poisoning include [[myocardial ischemia]], [[atrial fibrillation]], [[pneumonia]], [[pulmonary edema]], [[hyperglycemia|high blood sugar]], [[lactic acidosis]], [[rhabdomyolysis|muscle necrosis]], [[acute kidney failure]], [[skin lesion]]s, and visual and auditory problems.{{cite journal|author=Choi IS|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: systemic manifestations and complications|journal=Journal of Korean Medical Science|date=June 2001|pages=253–61|volume=16|issue=3|pmid=11410684|url=http://jkms.org/DOIx.php?id=10.3346/jkms.2001.16.3.253|doi-access=free |doi=10.3346/jkms.2001.16.3.253|pmc=3054741}}{{cite journal |author=Marius-Nunez AL |title=Myocardial infarction with normal coronary arteries after acute exposure to carbon monoxide |journal=Chest |volume=97 |issue=2 |pages=491–94 |date=February 1990 |pmid=2298080 |doi=10.1378/chest.97.2.491}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Gandini C, Castoldi AF, Candura SM, Locatelli C, Butera R, Priori S, Manzo L |title=Carbon monoxide cardiotoxicity |journal=Journal of Toxicology. Clinical Toxicology |volume=39 |issue=1 |pages=35–44 |year=2001 |pmid=11327225 |doi=10.1081/CLT-100102878}}{{cite journal |author=Sokal JA |title=The effect of exposure duration on the blood level of glucose, pyruvate and lactate in acute carbon monoxide intoxication in man |journal=Journal of Applied Toxicology: JAT |volume=5 |issue=6 |pages=395–97 |date=December 1985 |pmid=4078220 |doi=10.1002/jat.2550050611}} One of the major concerns following acute carbon monoxide poisoning is the severe delayed neurological manifestations that may occur. Problems may include difficulty with higher intellectual functions, [[memory loss|short-term memory loss]], [[dementia]], [[amnesia]], [[psychosis]], irritability, a strange [[gait]], speech disturbances, [[Parkinson's disease]]-like syndromes, [[cortical blindness]], and a [[Depression (mood)|depressed mood]].{{cite journal|author=Choi IS|title=Delayed neurologic sequelae in carbon monoxide intoxication|journal=Archives of Neurology|volume=40|issue=7|pages=433–35|date=July 1983|pmid=6860181|doi=10.1001/archneur.1983.04050070063016|url=http://archneur.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=582033|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819232412/http://archneur.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=582033|archivedate=2012-08-19|df=}} Depression may occur in those who did not have pre-existing depression.{{cite journal|vauthors=Roohi F, Kula RW, Mehta N |title=Twenty-nine years after carbon monoxide intoxication|journal=Clinical Neurology and Neurosurgery|date=July 2001|pages=92–95|volume=103|issue=2|pmid=11516551|doi=10.1016/S0303-8467(01)00119-6}} These delayed neurological [[sequelae]] may occur in up to 50% of poisoned people after 2 to 40 days. It is difficult to predict who will develop delayed sequelae; however, advanced age, loss of consciousness while poisoned, and initial neurological abnormalities may increase the chance of developing delayed symptoms.{{cite journal|vauthors=Myers RA, Snyder SK, Emhoff TA |title=Subacute sequelae of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Annals of Emergency Medicine|volume=14|issue=12|pages=1163–67|date=December 1985|pmid=4061987|doi=10.1016/S0196-0644(85)81022-2}} One classic sign of carbon monoxide poisoning is more often seen in the dead rather than the living – people have been described as looking red-cheeked and healthy (see below). However, since this "cherry-red" appearance is common only in the deceased, and is unusual in living people, it is not considered a useful diagnostic sign in clinical medicine. In pathological (autopsy) examination the ruddy appearance of carbon monoxide poisoning is notable because unembalmed dead persons are normally bluish and pale, whereas dead carbon-monoxide poisoned persons may simply appear unusually lifelike in coloration.{{cite journal|author=Simini B|title=Cherry-red discolouration in carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=Lancet| volume=352|issue=9134| page=1154|date=October 1998|pmid=9798630|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(05)79807-X}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Brooks DE, Lin E, Ahktar J |title=What is cherry red, and who cares?|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |date=February 2002|pages=213–14|volume=22|issue=2|pmid=11858933|doi=10.1016/S0736-4679(01)00469-3}} The colorant effect of carbon monoxide in such postmortem circumstances is thus analogous to its use as a red colorant in the commercial meat-packing industry. === Chronic poisoning === Chronic exposure to relatively low levels of carbon monoxide may cause persistent headaches, lightheadedness, depression, confusion, memory loss, nausea, hearing disorders and vomiting.{{cite journal|vauthors=Fawcett TA, Moon RE, Fracica PJ, Mebane GY, Theil DR, Piantadosi CA |title=Warehouse workers' headache. Carbon monoxide poisoning from propane-fueled forklifts|journal=Journal of Occupational Medicine|date=January 1992|pages=12–15|volume=34|issue=1|pmid=1552375}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/939229378|title=The Nordic Expert Group for criteria documentation of health risks from chemicals. 142, Occupational exposure to chemicals and hearing impairment|last=Johnson|first= Ann-Christin|date=2009|publisher=University of Gothenburg|others=Morata, Thais C.|isbn=978-9185971213|location=Göteborg|oclc=939229378}} It is unknown whether low-level chronic exposure may cause permanent neurological damage. Typically, upon removal from exposure to carbon monoxide, symptoms usually resolve themselves, unless there has been an episode of severe acute poisoning. However, one case noted permanent memory loss and learning problems after a 3-year exposure to relatively low levels of carbon monoxide from a faulty furnace.{{cite journal|author=Ryan CM|title=Memory disturbances following chronic, low-level carbon monoxide exposure|journal=Archives of Clinical Neuropsychology|year=1990|pages=59–67|volume=5|issue=1|pmid=14589544|doi=10.1016/0887-6177(90)90007-C}} Chronic exposure may worsen cardiovascular symptoms in some people. Chronic carbon monoxide exposure might increase the risk of developing atherosclerosis.{{cite journal|last=Davutoglu|first=V|title=Chronic carbon monoxide exposure is associated with the increases in carotid intima-media thickness and C-reactive protein level|journal=Tohoku J Exp Med|date=November 2009|volume=219|issue=3|pages=201–06|doi=10.1620/tjem.219.201|pmid=19851048}}{{cite book|last=Shephard|first=Roy|title=Carbon Monoxide The Silent Killer|year=1983|publisher=Charles C Thomas|location=Springfield Illinois|pages=93–96}} Long-term exposures to carbon monoxide present the greatest risk to persons with [[coronary heart disease]] and in females who are pregnant.{{cite journal|doi=10.1056/NEJM198911233212102|vauthors=Allred EN, Bleecker ER, Chaitman BR, Dahms TE, Gottlieb SO, Hackney JD, Pagano M, Selvester RH, Walden SM, Warren J |title=Short-term effects of carbon monoxide exposure on the exercise performance of subjects with coronary artery disease|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|date=Nov 1989|pages=1426–32|volume=321|issue=21|pmid=2682242|url=}} In experimental animals, carbon monoxide appears to worsen noise-induced hearing loss at noise exposure conditions that would have limited effects on hearing otherwise.{{cite journal|last1=Fechter|first1=LD|title=Promotion of noise-induced hearing loss by chemical contaminants|journal=Journal of toxicology and environmental health. Part A|date=2004|volume=67|issue=8–10|pages=727–40|doi=10.1080/15287390490428206|pmid=15192865}} In humans, hearing loss has been reported following carbon monoxide poisoning. Unlike the findings in animal studies, noise exposure was not a necessary factor for the auditory problems to occur. == Causes == {| class="wikitable" style = "float: right; margin-left:15px; text-align:center" !Concentration !Source |- |0.1 ppm |Natural atmosphere level ([[MOPITT]]){{cite book | author =Committee on Medical and Biological Effects of Environmental Pollutants | title = Carbon Monoxide | publisher = National Academy of Sciences| location = Washington, DC| year =1977 | page = 29| doi = | isbn =0309026318 }} |- |0.5 to 5 ppm |Average level in homes{{cite web| title =An Introduction to Indoor Air Quality: Carbon Monoxide (CO)| author =Green W| publisher =United States Environmental Protection Agency| url =http://www.epa.gov/iaq/co.html| doi =| accessdate =2008-12-16| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20081218112704/http://www.epa.gov/iaq/co.html| archivedate =2008-12-18| df =}} |- |5 to 15 ppm |Near properly adjusted gas stoves in homes |- |100 to 200 ppm |Exhaust from automobiles in the [[Mexico City]] central area{{cite book | last = Singer | first = Siegfried Fred | title = The Changing Global Environment | publisher = [[D. Reidel]] Publishing Company| location = Dordrecht| page = 90| doi = | isbn = }} |- |5,000 ppm |Exhaust from a home wood fire{{cite web | title =What Do Carbon Monoxide Levels Mean? | author =Gosink T | work =Alaska Science Forum | publisher =Geophysical Institute, University of Alaska Fairbanks | date =1983-01-28 | url =http://www.gi.alaska.edu/ScienceForum/ASF5/588.html | accessdate =2008-12-16 | deadurl =no | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20081225113654/http://www.gi.alaska.edu/ScienceForum/ASF5/588.html | archivedate =2008-12-25 | df = }} |- |7,000 ppm |Undiluted warm car exhaust without a [[catalytic converter]] |- |30,000 ppm |[[Afterdamp]] following an explosion in a coal mine{{citation | last = Roberts | first = H C W | title = Report on the causes of, and circumstances attending, the explosion which occurred at Easington Colliery, County Durham, on the 29th May, 1951. | date = September 1952 | publisher = Her Majesty's Stationery Office | publication-place = London | series = Cmd 8646 | format = PDF | url = http://hdl.handle.net/1842/5365 | page = 39 }} |} Carbon monoxide is a product of combustion of organic matter under conditions of restricted oxygen supply, which prevents complete [[oxidation]] to [[carbon dioxide]] (CO2). Sources of carbon monoxide include cigarette smoke, house fires, faulty [[furnace]]s, heaters, [[wood-burning stove]]s,{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/man-died-from-carbon-monoxide-poisoning-after-using-heat-beads-in-greystanes-home-20150718-gif8d8.html|title=Man died from carbon monoxide poisoning after using 'heat beads' in Greystanes home|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150719131747/http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/man-died-from-carbon-monoxide-poisoning-after-using-heat-beads-in-greystanes-home-20150718-gif8d8.html|archivedate=2015-07-19|df=}} [[internal combustion]] [[vehicle exhaust]], [[electrical generator]]s, [[propane]]-fueled equipment such as portable stoves, and gasoline-powered tools such as [[leaf blower]]s, lawn mowers, high-pressure washers, concrete cutting saws, power trowels, and welders.{{cite journal|vauthors=Marc B, Bouchez-Buvry A, Wepierre JL, Boniol L, Vaquero P, Garnier M |title=Carbon-monoxide poisoning in young drug addicts due to indoor use of a gasoline-powered generator|journal=Journal of Clinical Forensic Medicine|volume=8|issue=2|pages=54–56|date=June 2001|pmid=16083675|doi=10.1054/jcfm.2001.0474}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Johnson C, Moran J, Paine S, Anderson H, Breysse P |title=Abatement of toxic levels of carbon monoxide in Seattle ice-skating rinks|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=65|issue=10|pages=1087–90|date=October 1975|pmid=1163706|doi=10.2105/AJPH.65.10.1087|pmc=1776025}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/co/|title=NIOSH Carbon Monoxide Hazards from Small Gasoline Powered Engines|accessdate=2007-10-15|publisher=United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071029032750/http://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/co/|archivedate=2007-10-29|df=}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Fife CE, Smith LA, Maus EA, McCarthy JJ, Koehler MZ, Hawkins T, Hampson NB |title=Dying to play video games: carbon monoxide poisoning from electrical generators used after hurricane Ike |journal=Pediatrics |volume=123 |issue=6 |pages=e1035–38 |date=June 2009 |pmid=19482736 |doi=10.1542/peds.2008-3273}}{{cite report|author=Emmerich, SJ|date=July 2011|title=Measured CO Concentrations at NIST IAQ Test House from Operation of Portable Electric Generators in Attached Garage – Interim Report|url=https://www.nist.gov/manuscript-publication-search.cfm?pub_id=907771|publisher=United States National Institute of Standards and Technology|accessdate=2012-04-18|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130224044200/http://nist.gov/manuscript-publication-search.cfm?pub_id=907771|archivedate=2013-02-24|df=}} Exposure typically occurs when equipment is used in buildings or semi-enclosed spaces. Riding in the back of [[pickup trucks]] has led to poisoning in children.{{cite journal|vauthors=Hampson NB, Norkool DM |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning in children riding in the back of pickup trucks|journal=JAMA|volume=267|issue=4|pages=538–40|date=January 1992|pmid=1370334|doi=10.1001/jama.267.4.538|url=}} Idling automobiles with the exhaust pipe blocked by snow has led to the poisoning of car occupants.{{cite journal|author=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)|title=Carbon monoxide poisonings associated with snow-obstructed vehicle exhaust systems—Philadelphia and New York City, January 1996|journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report|volume=45|issue=1|pages=1–3|date=January 1996|pmid=8531914|url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00039929.htm|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170624015949/https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00039929.htm|archivedate=2017-06-24|df=}} Any perforation between the exhaust manifold and shroud can result in exhaust gases reaching the cabin. Generators and propulsion engines on boats, especially houseboats, has resulted in fatal carbon monoxide exposures.{{cite journal |author=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)|title=Houseboat-associated carbon monoxide poisonings on Lake Powell—Arizona and Utah, 2000|journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report|volume=49|issue=49|pages=1105–1108|date=December 2000|pmid=11917924|url=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/coboating/|title=NIOSH Carbon Monoxide Dangers in Boating|accessdate=2007-10-15|publisher=United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013113132/http://cdc.gov/niosh/topics/coboating/|archivedate=2007-10-13|df=}} Poisoning may also occur following the use of a self-contained underwater breathing apparatus (SCUBA) due to faulty [[diving air compressor]]s.{{cite journal|vauthors=Austin CC, Ecobichon DJ, Dussault G, Tirado C |title=Carbon monoxide and water vapor contamination of compressed breathing air for firefighters and divers|journal=Journal of Toxicology and Environmental Health|volume=52|issue=5|pages=403–23|date=December 1997|pmid=9388533|doi=10.1080/00984109708984073}} In caves carbon monoxide can build up in enclosed chambers due to the presence of decomposing organic matter.{{cite book |last=Dart| first= RC |chapter= |title=Medical toxicology |publisher=Williams & Wilkins| location=Philadelphia |year=2004|page=1169| isbn=0781728452}} In coal mines incomplete combustion may occur during explosions resulting in the production of [[afterdamp]]. The gas is up to 3% CO and may be fatal after just a single breath. Following an explosion in a colliery, adjacent interconnected mines may become dangerous due to the afterdamp leaking from mine to mine. Such an incident followed the [[Trimdon Grange]] explosion which killed men in the [[Kelloe]] mine.{{citation | url = http://www.healeyhero.co.uk/rescue/pits/Trimdon_Grange/Trimdon3.htm#top | title = Trimdon Grange, Durham. 16th February 1882 | accessdate = 22 May 2012 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170330072644/http://www.healeyhero.co.uk/rescue/pits/Trimdon_Grange/Trimdon3.htm#top | archivedate = 30 March 2017 | df = }} Another source of poisoning is exposure to the organic solvent [[dichloromethane]], found in some [[paint stripper]]s,{{cite journal|last=van Veen|first=MP|author2=Fortezza F |author3=Spaans E |author4=Mensinga TT |title=Non-professional paint stripping, model prediction and experimental validation of indoor dichloromethane levels|journal=Indoor Air|year=2002|volume=12|issue=2|pages=92–97|doi=10.1034/j.1600-0668.2002.01109.x|pmid=12216472}} as the metabolism of dichloromethane produces carbon monoxide.{{cite journal|vauthors=Kubic VL, Anders MW |title=Metabolism of dihalomethanes to carbon monoxide. II. In vitro studies|journal=Drug Metabolism and Disposition|date=March 1975|pages=104–12|volume=3|issue=2|pmid=236156}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Dueñas A, Felipe S, Ruiz-Mambrilla M, Martín-Escudero JC, García-Calvo C |title=CO poisoning caused by inhalation of CH3Cl contained in personal defense spray|journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine|volume=18|issue=1|pages=120–21|date=January 2000|pmid=10674554|doi=10.1016/S0735-6757(00)90070-6}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Varon J, Marik PE, Fromm RE, Gueler A |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: A review for clinicians|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |year=1999|pages=87–93|volume=17|issue=1|pmid=9950394|doi=10.1016/S0736-4679(98)00128-0}} == Pathophysiology == The precise mechanisms by which the effects of carbon monoxide are induced upon bodily systems, are complex and not yet fully understood. Known mechanisms include carbon monoxide binding to [[hemoglobin]], [[myoglobin]] and [[mitochondrial]] [[cytochrome oxidase]] and restricting oxygen supply, and carbon monoxide causing [[brain]] [[lipid peroxidation]].{{cite journal|author=Bateman DN|title=Carbon Monoxide|journal=Medicine|volume=31|issue=10|page=233|date=October 2003|doi=10.1383/medc.31.10.41.27810}} === Hemoglobin === [[File:Hemoglobin saturation curve.svg|thumb|Carbon monoxide shifts the oxygen-dissociation curve to the left.]] Carbon monoxide has a higher diffusion coefficient compared to oxygen, and the only enzyme in the human body that produces carbon monoxide is [[heme oxygenase]], which is located in all cells and breaks down [[heme]]. Under normal conditions, carbon monoxide levels in the [[Blood plasma|plasma]] are approximately 0 [[Millimeter of mercury|mmHg]] because it has a higher diffusion coefficient and the body easily gets rid of any CO made.{{cite book|title=USMLE Step 1 Lecture Notes: Physiology|year=2011|author=Dunn, Robert B.|author2=Kudrath, W. |author3=Passo, SS |author4=Wilson, LB|pages=167–68|chapter=7-3}} When CO is not ventilated it binds to hemoglobin, which is the principal oxygen-carrying compound in blood; this produces a compound known as [[carboxyhemoglobin]]. The traditional belief is that carbon monoxide toxicity arises from the formation of carboxyhemoglobin, which decreases the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood and inhibits the transport, delivery, and utilization of oxygen by the body. The affinity between hemoglobin and carbon monoxide is approximately 230 times stronger than the affinity between hemoglobin and oxygen so hemoglobin binds to carbon monoxide in preference to oxygen.{{cite journal|vauthors=Townsend CL, Maynard RL |title=Effects on health of prolonged exposure to low concentrations of carbon monoxide|journal=Occupational and Environmental Medicine|volume=59|issue=10|pages=708–11|date=October 2002|pmid=12356933|pmc=1740215|doi=10.1136/oem.59.10.708|url=}}{{cite journal|author=Haldane J|title=The action of carbonic oxide on man|journal=The Journal of Physiology|year=1895|pages=430–62|volume=18|url=http://jp.physoc.org/content/18/5-6/430.full.pdf|pmid=16992272|issue=5–6|pmc=1514663|doi=10.1113/jphysiol.1895.sp000578|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708152937/http://jp.physoc.org/content/18/5-6/430.full.pdf|archivedate=2011-07-08|df=}} Hemoglobin is a [[Tetrameric protein|tetramer]] with four oxygen binding sites. The binding of carbon monoxide at one of these sites increases the oxygen affinity of the remaining three sites, which causes the hemoglobin molecule to retain oxygen that would otherwise be delivered to the tissue.{{cite journal|vauthors=Gorman D, Drewry A, Huang YL, Sames C |title=The clinical toxicology of carbon monoxide|journal=Toxicology|date=May 2003|pages=25–38|volume=187|issue=1|pmid=12679050|doi=10.1016/S0300-483X(03)00005-2}} This situation is described as carbon monoxide shifting the [[oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve|oxygen dissociation curve]] to the left. Because of the increased affinity between hemoglobin and oxygen during carbon monoxide poisoning, little oxygen will actually be released in the tissues. This causes hypoxic tissue injury. Hemoglobin acquires a bright red color when converted into carboxyhemoglobin, so poisoned cadavers and even commercial meats treated with carbon monoxide acquire an unnatural reddish hue. === Myoglobin === Carbon monoxide also binds to the [[hemeprotein]] [[myoglobin]]. It has a high affinity for myoglobin, about 60 times greater than that of oxygen. Carbon monoxide bound to myoglobin may impair its ability to utilize oxygen. This causes reduced [[cardiac output]] and [[hypotension]], which may result in [[brain ischemia]]. A delayed return of symptoms have been reported. This results following a recurrence of increased carboxyhemoglobin levels; this effect may be due to a late release of carbon monoxide from myoglobin, which subsequently binds to hemoglobin. === Cytochrome oxidase === Another mechanism involves effects on the mitochondrial respiratory enzyme chain that is responsible for effective tissue utilization of oxygen. Carbon monoxide binds to [[cytochrome oxidase]] with less affinity than oxygen, so it is possible that it requires significant intracellular hypoxia before binding.{{cite journal |vauthors=Gorman DF, Runciman WB |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=Anaesthesia and Intensive Care |volume=19 |issue=4 |pages=506–11 |date=November 1991 |pmid=1750629 |doi= |url=}} This binding interferes with aerobic metabolism and efficient [[adenosine triphosphate]] synthesis. Cells respond by switching to [[anaerobic metabolism]], causing [[Hypoxia (medical)|anoxia]], [[lactic acidosis]], and eventual cell death.{{cite journal|vauthors=Alonso JR, Cardellach F, Lopez S, Casademont J, Miro O |title=Carbon monoxide specifically inhibits cytochrome c oxidase of human mitochondrial respiratory chain|journal=Pharmacology & Toxicology|date=September 2003|pages=142–46|volume=93|issue=3|pmid=12969439|doi=10.1034/j.1600-0773.2003.930306.x}} The rate of [[Dissociation (chemistry)|dissociation]] between carbon monoxide and cytochrome oxidase is slow, causing a relatively prolonged impairment of [[oxidative metabolism]]. === Central nervous system effects === The mechanism that is thought to have a significant influence on delayed effects involves formed blood cells and chemical mediators, which cause brain [[lipid peroxidation]] (degradation of unsaturated fatty acids). Carbon monoxide causes [[endothelial]] cell and platelet release of [[nitric oxide]], and the formation of [[oxygen free radicals]] including [[peroxynitrite]]. In the brain this causes further mitochondrial dysfunction, [[capillary]] leakage, [[leukocyte]] sequestration, and [[apoptosis]].{{cite journal|author=Blumenthal I|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine|date=June 2001|pages=270–72|volume=94|issue=6|pmid=11387414|url=http://www.jrsm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=11387414|format=Free full text|pmc=1281520|doi=10.1177/014107680109400604}} The result of these effects is [[lipid peroxidation]], which causes delayed reversible [[Demyelinating disease|demyelinization]] of [[white matter]] in the central nervous system known as [[Grinker myelinopathy]], which can lead to [[edema]] and [[necrosis]] within the brain. This brain damage occurs mainly during the recovery period. This may result in cognitive defects, especially affecting memory and learning, and movement disorders. These disorders are typically related to damage to the cerebral [[white matter]] and [[basal ganglia]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Fan HC, Wang AC, Lo CP, Chang KP, Chen SJ |title=Damage of cerebellar white matter due to carbon monoxide poisoning: a case report|journal=[[The American Journal of Emergency Medicine]]|volume=27|issue=6|pages=757.e5–e7|date=July 2009|pmid=19751650|doi=10.1016/j.ajem.2008.10.021}} Hallmark pathological changes following poisoning are bilateral necrosis of the white matter, [[globus pallidus]], [[cerebellum]], [[hippocampus]] and the [[cerebral cortex]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Prockop LD, Chichkova RI |title=Carbon monoxide intoxication: an updated review|journal=Journal of the Neurological Sciences|date=Nov 2007|pages=122–30|volume=262|issue=1–2|pmid=17720201|doi=10.1016/j.jns.2007.06.037}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Fukuhara M, Abe I, Matsumura K, Kaseda S, Yamashita Y, Shida K, Kawashima H, Fujishima M |title=Circadian variations of blood pressure in patients with sequelae of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=American Journal of Hypertension |volume=9|issue=4 Part 1|pages=300–05|date=April 1996|pmid=8722431|doi=10.1016/0895-7061(95)00342-8}} === Pregnancy === Carbon monoxide poisoning in pregnant women may cause severe adverse [[fetus|fetal]] effects. Poisoning causes fetal tissue [[Hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]] by decreasing the release of maternal oxygen to the fetus. Carbon monoxide also crosses the [[placenta]] and combines with [[fetal hemoglobin]], causing more direct fetal tissue hypoxia. Additionally, fetal hemoglobin has a 10 to 15% higher affinity for carbon monoxide than adult hemoglobin, causing more severe poisoning in the fetus than in the adult. Elimination of carbon monoxide is slower in the fetus, leading to an accumulation of the toxic chemical.{{cite journal|vauthors=Greingor JL, Tosi JM, Ruhlmann S, Aussedat M |title=Acute carbon monoxide intoxication during pregnancy. One case report and review of the literature|journal=Emergency Medicine Journal|volume=18|issue=5|pages=399–401|date=September 2001|pmid=11559621|pmc=1725677|doi=10.1136/emj.18.5.399|url=http://emj.bmj.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=11559621}} The level of fetal morbidity and mortality in acute carbon monoxide poisoning is significant, so despite mild maternal poisoning or following maternal recovery, severe fetal poisoning or death may still occur.{{cite journal|vauthors=Farrow JR, Davis GJ, Roy TM, McCloud LC, Nichols GR |title=Fetal death due to nonlethal maternal carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Journal of Forensic Sciences|volume=35|issue=6|pages=1448–52|date=November 1990|pmid=2262778}} == Diagnosis == [[File:Co monitor.JPG|thumb|Finger tip [[carboxyhemoglobin]] saturation monitor (SpCO%). Note: This is not the same as a pulse oximeter (SpO2%), although some models (such as this one) do measure both the oxygen and carbon monoxide saturation.]] [[File:Breath CO Monitor.jpg|thumb|Breath CO monitor displaying carbon monoxide concentration of an exhaled breath sample (in ppm) with its corresponding percent concentration of carboxyhemoglobin.]] As many symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning also occur with many other types of poisonings and infections (such as the flu), the diagnosis is often difficult.{{cite journal|vauthors=Bennetto L, Powter L, Scolding NJ |title=Accidental carbon monoxide poisoning presenting without a history of exposure: A case report|journal=Journal of Medical Case Reports|volume=2|issue=1|page=118|date=April 2008|pmid=18430228|doi=10.1186/1752-1947-2-118|pmc=2390579}} A history of potential carbon monoxide exposure, such as being exposed to a residential fire, may suggest poisoning, but the diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the levels of carbon monoxide in the blood. This can be determined by measuring the amount of [[carboxyhemoglobin]] compared to the amount of [[hemoglobin]] in the blood. The ratio of carboxyhemoglobin to hemoglobin molecules in an average person may be up to 5%, although cigarette smokers who smoke two packs per day may have levels up to 9%.{{cite book|veditors=Ford MD, Delaney KA, Ling LJ, Erickson T |title=Clinical Toxicology|year=2001|page=1046|publisher=WB Saunders Company|isbn=0721654851}} In symptomatic poisoned people they are often in the 10–30% range, while persons who die may have postmortem blood levels of 30–90%.Sato K, Tamaki K, Hattori H, et al. Determination of total hemoglobin in forensic blood samples with special reference to carboxyhemoglobin analysis. For. Sci. Int. 48: 89–96, 1990.R. Baselt, ''Disposition of Toxic Drugs and Chemicals in Man'', 8th edition, Biomedical Publications, Foster City, CA, 2008, pp. 237–41. As people may continue to experience significant symptoms of CO poisoning long after their blood carboxyhemoglobin concentration has returned to normal, presenting to examination with a normal carboxyhemoglobin level (which may happen in late states of poisoning) does not rule out poisoning.{{cite journal|vauthors=Keleş A, Demircan A, Kurtoğlu G |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: how many patients do we miss?|journal=European Journal of Emergency Medicine |volume=15|issue=3|pages=154–57|date=June 2008|pmid=18460956|doi=10.1097/MEJ.0b013e3282efd519}} ===Measuring=== Carbon monoxide may be quantitated in blood using [[spectrophotometry|spectrophotometric]] methods or [[chromatography|chromatographic techniques]] in order to confirm a diagnosis of poisoning in a person or to assist in the forensic investigation of a case of fatal exposure. A [[CO-oximeter]] can be used to determine carboxyhemoglobin levels.{{cite journal|vauthors=Rodkey FL, Hill TA, Pitts LL, Robertson RF |title=Spectrophotometric measurement of carboxyhemoglobin and methemoglobin in blood|journal=Clinical Chemistry|volume=25|issue=8|pages=1388–93|date=August 1979|pmid=455674|doi=|url=http://www.clinchem.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=455674|accessdate=2009-07-17}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Rees PJ, Chilvers C, Clark TJ |title=Evaluation of methods used to estimate inhaled dose of carbon monoxide|journal=Thorax|volume=35|issue=1|pages=47–51|date=January 1980|pmid=7361284|pmc=471219|doi= 10.1136/thx.35.1.47|url=http://thorax.bmj.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=7361284}} Pulse [[CO-oximeter]]s estimate carboxyhemoglobin with a non-invasive finger clip similar to a [[pulse oximeter]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Coulange M, Barthelemy A, Hug F, Thierry AL, De Haro L|title=Reliability of new pulse CO-oximeter in victims of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine|volume=35|issue=2|pages=107–11|date=March 2008|pmid=18500075|doi=|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/8084|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110625021038/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/8084|archivedate=2011-06-25|df=}} These devices function by passing various wavelengths of light through the fingertip and measuring the light absorption of the different types of hemoglobin in the capillaries.{{Cite journal|last = Maisel | first = William | authorlink = |author2=Roger J. Lewis | title = Noninvasive Measurement of Carboxyhemoglobin: How Accurate is Accurate Enough? | journal = Annals of Emergency Medicine | volume = 56 | issue = 4 | pages = 389–91 | publisher = | location = Boston, MA | year = 2010 | doi=10.1016/j.annemergmed.2010.05.025}} The use of a regular [[pulse oximeter]] is not effective in the diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning as people with carbon monoxide poisoning may have a normal [[oxygen saturation]] level on a pulse oximeter.{{cite journal|vauthors=Vegfors M, Lennmarken C |title=Carboxyhaemoglobinaemia and pulse oximetry|journal=British Journal of Anaesthesia|volume=66|issue=5|pages=625–626|date=May 1991|pmid=2031826|doi=10.1093/bja/66.5.625}} This is due to the carboxyhemoglobin being misrepresented as oxyhemoglobin.{{cite journal|vauthors=Barker SJ, Tremper KK |title=The effect of carbon monoxide inhalation on pulse oximetry and transcutaneous PO2|journal=Anesthesiology|volume=66|issue=5|pages=677–79|date=May 1987|pmid=3578881|doi=10.1097/00000542-198705000-00014}} [[Carbon monoxide breath monitor|Breath CO monitoring]] offers an alternative to pulse CO-oximetry. Carboxyhemoglobin levels have been shown to have a strong correlation with breath CO concentration.{{cite journal|first=M.|last=Jarvis|year=1986|title=Low cost carbon monoxide monitors in smoking assessment|journal=Thorax|pages=886–87|doi=10.1136/thx.41.11.886|volume=41|issue=11|pmc=460516}}{{cite journal|first=Nicholas|last=Wald|year=1981|title=Carbon monoxide in breath in relation to smoking and carboxyhaemoglobin levels|journal=Thorax|pages=366–69|doi=10.1136/thx.36.5.366|pmid=7314006|pmc=471511|volume=36|issue=5}} However, many of these devices require the user to inhale deeply and hold their breath to allow the CO in the blood to escape into the lung before the measurement can be made. As this is not possible in people who are unresponsive, these devices may not appropriate for use in on-scene emergency care detection of CO poisoning. === Differential diagnosis === There are many conditions to be considered in the differential diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning.{{cite journal |vauthors=Kao LW, Nañagas KA |title=Toxicity associated with carbon monoxide |journal=Clinics in Laboratory Medicine |volume=26 |issue=1 |pages=99–125 |date=March 2006 |pmid=16567227 |doi=10.1016/j.cll.2006.01.005}}{{cite web | last =Shochat | first =Guy N | title =Toxicity, Carbon Monoxide | publisher =[[emedicine]] | date =17 February 2009 | url =http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/819987-overview | accessdate =2009-04-27 | deadurl =no | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20090309072832/http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/819987-overview | archivedate =9 March 2009 | df = }} The earliest symptoms, especially from low level exposures, are often non-specific and readily confused with other illnesses, typically [[influenza|flu-like viral syndromes]], [[clinical depression|depression]], [[chronic fatigue syndrome]], [[chest pain]], and [[migraine]] or other headaches.{{cite journal | vauthors=Ilano AL, Raffin TA | title=Management of carbon monoxide poisoning | journal=Chest | date=Jan 1990 | pages=165–69 | volume=97 | issue=1 | pmid=2403894 | doi=10.1378/chest.97.1.165 }} Carbon monoxide has been called a "great mimicker" due to the presentation of poisoning being diverse and nonspecific. Other conditions included in the differential diagnosis include [[acute respiratory distress syndrome]], [[altitude sickness]], [[lactic acidosis]], [[diabetic ketoacidosis]], [[meningitis]], [[methemoglobinemia]], or [[Opioid overdose|opioid]] or toxic alcohol poisoning. == Prevention == [[File:CO DETECTOR (cropped).JPG|thumb|Carbon monoxide detector connected to a North American power outlet]] === Detectors === [[File:COMonitor.jpg|thumb|A carbon monoxide monitor clipped to the uniform of a paramedic]] Prevention remains a vital [[public health]] issue, requiring public education on the safe operation of appliances, heaters, fireplaces, and internal-combustion engines, as well as increased emphasis on the installation of [[carbon monoxide detector]]s.{{cite journal|vauthors=Ernst A, Zibrak JD |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=339|issue=22|pages=1603–08|date=November 1998|pmid=9828249|doi=10.1056/NEJM199811263392206|url=http://content.nejm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=short&pmid=9828249&promo=ONFLNS19}} Carbon monoxide is tasteless and odourless, and therefore can not be detected by visual cues or smell.{{cite journal |title=Compressed breathing air – the potential for evil from within |vauthors=Millar IL, Mouldey PG |year=2008 |volume=38 |issue=2 |pages=145–51 |journal=Diving and Hyperbaric Medicine |publisher=[[South Pacific Underwater Medicine Society]] |url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/7964 |accessdate=2013-04-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225063245/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/7964 |archivedate=2010-12-25 |df= |pmid=22692708 }} The United States [[Consumer Product Safety Commission]] has stated, "carbon monoxide detectors are as important to home safety as smoke detectors are," and recommends each home have at least one carbon monoxide detector, and preferably one on each level of the building. These devices, which are relatively inexpensive and widely available, are either battery- or AC-powered, with or without battery backup.{{cite web|last=Lipinski|first=Edward R|title=Keeping Watch on Carbon Monoxide|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 14, 1999|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/14/nyregion/home-clinic-keeping-watch-on-carbon-monoxide.html|accessdate=2009-09-09|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110623100533/http://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/14/nyregion/home-clinic-keeping-watch-on-carbon-monoxide.html|archivedate=June 23, 2011|df=}} In buildings, carbon monoxide detectors are usually installed around heaters and other equipment. If a relatively high level of carbon monoxide is detected, the device sounds an alarm, giving people the chance to evacuate and ventilate the building.{{cite journal |vauthors=Krenzelok EP, Roth R, Full R |title=Carbon monoxide ... the silent killer with an audible solution |journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine |date=September 1996 |pages=484–86 |volume=14 |issue=5 |pmid=8765117 |doi=10.1016/S0735-6757(96)90159-X }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Yoon SS, Macdonald SC, Parrish RG |title=Deaths from unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning and potential for prevention with carbon monoxide detectors |journal=JAMA |date=March 1998 |pages=685–87 |volume=279 |issue=9 |pmid=9496987 |doi=10.1001/jama.279.9.685 }} Unlike [[smoke detector]]s, carbon monoxide detectors do not need to be placed near ceiling level. The use of carbon monoxide detectors has been standardized in many areas. In the US, NFPA 720-2009,{{cite book|title=NFPA 720: Standard for the Installation of Carbon Monoxide (CO) Detection and Warning Equipment|publisher=National Fire Protection Agency|location=Quincy, MA|year=2009|pages=|isbn=}} the carbon monoxide detector guidelines published by the [[National Fire Protection Association]], mandates the placement of carbon monoxide detectors/alarms on every level of the residence, including the basement, in addition to outside sleeping areas. In new homes, AC-powered detectors must have battery backup and be interconnected to ensure early warning of occupants at all levels. NFPA 720-2009 is the first national carbon monoxide standard to address devices in non-residential buildings. These guidelines, which now pertain to schools, healthcare centers, nursing homes and other non-residential buildings, include three main points: :1. A secondary power supply (battery backup) must operate all carbon monoxide notification appliances for at least 12 hours, :2. Detectors must be on the ceiling in the same room as permanently installed fuel-burning appliances, and :3. Detectors must be located on every habitable level and in every [[HVAC]] zone of the building. Gas organizations will often recommend to get gas appliances serviced at least once a year.{{cite web|title=Gas Safety in the Home |publisher=UK Gas Safe Register |accessdate=2013-05-27 |url=http://www.gassaferegister.co.uk/advice/being_gas_safe.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502012946/http://gassaferegister.co.uk/advice/being_gas_safe.aspx |archivedate=2013-05-02 |df= }} === Legal requirements === The NFPA standard is not necessarily enforced by law. As of April 2006, the US state of Massachusetts requires detectors to be present in all residences with potential CO sources, regardless of building age and whether they are owner-occupied or rented.{{cite web|url=http://www.malegislature.gov/Laws/GeneralLaws/PartI/TitleXX/Chapter148/Section26F1~2|title=MGL Ch. 148 §28F{{frac|1|2}} – Nicole's Law, effective March 31, 2006|work=malegislature.gov|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121230154311/http://www.malegislature.gov/Laws/GeneralLaws/PartI/TitleXX/Chapter148/Section26F1~2|archivedate=December 30, 2012|df=}} This is enforced by municipal inspectors, and was inspired by the death of 7-year-old Nicole Garofalo in 2005 due to snow blocking a home heating vent.{{cite web |url=http://www.lawlib.state.ma.us/subject/about/carbonmonoxide.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130305145343/http://www.lawlib.state.ma.us/subject/about/carbonmonoxide.html |archivedate=2013-03-05 |df= }} Other jurisdictions may have no requirement or only mandate detectors for new construction or at time of sale. Despite similar deaths in vehicles with clogged exhaust pipes (for example in the [[Northeastern United States blizzard of 1978]] and [[February 2013 nor'easter]]) and the commercial availability of the equipment, there is no legal requirement for automotive CO detectors.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} ===World Health Organization recommendations=== The following guideline values (ppm values rounded) and periods of time-weighted average exposures have been determined in such a way that the carboxyhaemoglobin (COHb) level of 2.5% is not exceeded, even when a normal subject engages in light or moderate exercise: * 100 mg/m3 (87 ppm) for 15 min * 60 mg/m3 (52 ppm) for 30 min * 30 mg/m3 (26 ppm) for 1 h * 10 mg/m3 (9 ppm) for 8 h For indoor air quality 7 mg/m3 (6 ppm) for 24 h (so as not to exceed 2% COHb for chronic exposure) == Treatment == {| class="wikitable" style = "float: right; margin-left:15px; text-align:center;" |+ Time to remove 50% carboxy hemoglobin{{cite book|last1=Mathieu|first1=Daniel|title=Handbook on Hyperbaric Medicine|date=2006|publisher=Springer|location=[New York]|isbn=978-1402043765|edition=Online-Ausg.}} ! Oxygen pressure О2 ! Time |- |21% oxygen at normal atmospheric pressure (fresh air) | 5 hours 20 min |- |100% oxygen at normal atmospheric pressure (non-rebreather oxygen mask) | 1 hours 20 min |- |100% Hyperbaric oxygen (3 atmospheres absolute) | 23 min |} Initial treatment for carbon monoxide poisoning is to immediately remove the person from the exposure without endangering further people. Those who are unconscious may require [[Cardiopulmonary resuscitation|CPR]] on site. Administering [[oxygen]] via [[non-rebreather mask]] shortens the [[Biological half-life|half-life]] of carbon monoxide from 320 minutes, when breathing normal air, to only 80 minutes. Oxygen hastens the dissociation of carbon monoxide from [[carboxyhemoglobin]], thus turning it back into [[hemoglobin]].{{cite journal|author=Olson KR|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: Mechanisms, presentation, and controversies in management|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |volume=1|issue=3|pages=233–43|year=1984|pmid=6491241|doi=10.1016/0736-4679(84)90078-7}} Due to the possible severe effects in the fetus, pregnant women are treated with oxygen for longer periods of time than non-pregnant people.{{cite journal|author=Margulies JL|title=Acute carbon monoxide poisoning during pregnancy|journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine|volume=4|issue=6|pages=516–19|date=November 1986|pmid=3778597|doi=10.1016/S0735-6757(86)80008-0}} === Hyperbaric oxygen === [[File:HyperBaric Oxygen Therapy Chamber 2008.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|A person within a hyperbaric oxygen chamber]] [[Hyperbaric oxygen]] is also used in the treatment of carbon monoxide poisoning, as it may hasten dissociation of CO from carboxyhemoglobin and cytochrome oxidase{{cite journal|vauthors=Brown DB, Mueller GL, Golich FC |title=Hyperbaric oxygen treatment for carbon monoxide poisoning in pregnancy: a case report|journal=Aviation, Space, and Environmental Medicine|volume=63|issue=11|pages=1011–14|date=November 1992|pmid=1445151}} to a greater extent than normal oxygen. Hyperbaric oxygen at three times [[atmospheric pressure]] reduces the half life of carbon monoxide to 23 (~80/3 minutes) minutes, compared to 80 minutes for oxygen at regular atmospheric pressure. It may also enhance oxygen transport to the tissues by plasma, partially bypassing the normal transfer through hemoglobin. However, it is controversial whether hyperbaric oxygen actually offers any extra benefits over normal high flow oxygen, in terms of increased survival or improved long-term outcomes.{{Cite journal|last=Buckley|first=Nick A.|last2=Juurlink|first2=David N.|last3=Isbister|first3=Geoff|last4=Bennett|first4=Michael H.|last5=Lavonas|first5=Eric J.|date=2011-04-13|title=Hyperbaric oxygen for carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|issue=4|page=CD002041|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD002041.pub3|issn=1469-493X|pmid=21491385}}{{cite journal|author=Henry JA|title=Hyperbaric therapy for carbon monoxide poisoning: to treat or not to treat, that is the question|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|pages=149–150|year=2005|pmid=16390211|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00002}} {{cite journal|author=Olson KR|title=Hyperbaric oxygen or normobaric oxygen?|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|page=151; discussion 159–60|year=2005|pmid=16390212|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00003}}{{cite journal|author=Seger D|title=The myth|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|pages=155–56|year=2005|pmid=16390214|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00005}}{{cite journal|author=Thom SR|title=Hyperbaric oxygen therapy for carbon monoxide poisoning: Is it time to end the debates?|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|pages=157–58|year=2005|pmid=16390215|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00006}} There have been [[randomized controlled trial]]s in which the two treatment options have been compared;{{cite journal|vauthors=Scheinkestel CD, Bailey M, Myles PS, Jones K, Cooper DJ, Millar IL, Tuxen DV|title=Hyperbaric or normobaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning: a randomized controlled clinical trial|journal=[[The Medical Journal of Australia]]|date=March 1999|pages=203–10|volume=170|issue=5|pmid=10092916|url=http://www.mja.com.au/public/issues/mar1/scheink/scheink.html|format=Free full text|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905012917/https://www.mja.com.au/public/issues/mar1/scheink/scheink.html|archivedate=2008-09-05|df=}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Thom SR, Taber RL, Mendiguren II, Clark JM, Hardy KR, Fisher AB |title=Delayed neuropsychologic sequelae after carbon monoxide poisoning: prevention by treatment with hyperbaric oxygen|journal=Annals of Emergency Medicine|date=April 1995|pages=474–80|volume=25|issue=4|pmid=7710151|doi=10.1016/S0196-0644(95)70261-X}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Raphael JC, Elkharrat D, Jars-Guincestre MC, Chastang C, Chasles V, Vercken JB, Gajdos P |title=Trial of normobaric and hyperbaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide intoxication|journal=Lancet|date=August 1989|pages=414–19|volume=2|issue=8660|pmid=2569600|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(89)90592-8}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Ducasse JL, Celsis P, Marc-Vergnes JP|title=Non-comatose patients with acute carbon monoxide poisoning: hyperbaric or normobaric oxygenation?|journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine|date=March 1995|pages=9–15|volume=22|issue=1|pmid=7742714|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/2193|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811174818/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/2193|archivedate=2011-08-11|df=}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Mathieu D, Mathieu-Nolf M, Durak C, Wattel F, Tempe JP, Bouachour G, Sainty JM|title=Randomized prospective study comparing the effect of HBO vs 12 hours NBO in non-comatose CO-poisoned patients: results of the preliminary analysis|journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine|year=1996|page=7|volume=23|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/447|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110702235523/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/447|archivedate=2011-07-02|df=}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Weaver LK, Hopkins RO, Chan KJ, Churchill S, Elliott CG, Clemmer TP, Orme JF, Thomas FO, Morris AH |title=Hyperbaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|date=October 2002|pages=1057–67|volume=347|issue=14|pmid=12362006|doi=10.1056/NEJMoa013121}} of the six performed, four found hyperbaric oxygen improved outcome and two found no benefit for hyperbaric oxygen.{{cite journal|vauthors=Buckley NA, Isbister GK, Stokes B, Juurlink DN |title=Hyperbaric oxygen for carbon monoxide poisoning: a systematic review and critical analysis of the evidence|journal=Toxicological Reviews|year=2005|pages=75–92|volume=24|issue=2|pmid=16180928|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524020-00002}} Some of these trials have been criticized for apparent flaws in their implementation.{{cite journal|author=Gorman DF.|title=Hyperbaric or normobaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning: a randomised controlled clinical trial. Unfortunate methodological flaws|journal=The Medical Journal of Australia|date=June 1999|pages=563; author reply 564–65|volume=170|issue=11|pmid=10397050}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Scheinkestel CD, Jones K, Myles PS, Cooper DJ, Millar IL, Tuxen DV |title=Where to now with carbon monoxide poisoning?|journal=Emergency Medicine Australasia: EMA|date=April 2004|pages=151–54|volume=16|issue=2|pmid=15239731|doi=10.1111/j.1742-6723.2004.00567.x}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Isbister GK, McGettigan P, Harris I |title=Hyperbaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|date=February 2003|pages=557–60|volume=348|issue=6|pmid=12572577|doi=10.1056/NEJM200302063480615}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Buckley NA, Juurlink DN |title=Carbon monoxide treatment guidelines must acknowledge the limitations of the existing evidence |journal=American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine |volume=187 |issue=12 |page=1390 |date=June 2013 |pmid=23767905 |doi=10.1164/rccm.201212-2262LE}} A review of all the literature concluded that the role of hyperbaric oxygen is unclear and the available evidence neither confirms nor denies a medically meaningful benefit. The authors suggested a large, well designed, externally audited, multicentre trial to compare normal oxygen with hyperbaric oxygen. === Other === Further treatment for other complications such as [[seizure]], hypotension, cardiac abnormalities, [[pulmonary edema]], and [[acidosis]] may be required. Increased muscle activity and seizures should be treated with [[dantrolene]] or [[diazepam]]; diazepam should only be given with appropriate respiratory support. Hypotension requires treatment with intravenous fluids; [[vasopressor]]s may be required to treat myocardial depression.{{cite journal|author=Tomaszewski C|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning. Early awareness and intervention can save lives|journal=Postgraduate Medicine|volume=105|issue=1|pages=39–40, 43–48, 50|date=January 1999|pmid=9924492|doi=10.3810/pgm.1999.01.496}} [[Cardiac dysrhythmia]]s are treated with standard [[advanced cardiac life support]] protocols. If severe, metabolic acidosis is treated with [[sodium bicarbonate]]. Treatment with sodium bicarbonate is controversial as acidosis may increase tissue oxygen availability.{{cite journal|author=Peirce EC|title=Treating acidemia in carbon monoxide poisoning may be dangerous|journal=Journal of Hyperbaric Medicine|volume=1|issue=2|pages=87–97|year=1986|pmid=|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/4304|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110703000244/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/4304|archivedate=2011-07-03|df=}} Treatment of acidosis may only need to consist of oxygen therapy. The delayed development of neuropsychiatric impairment is one of the most serious complications of carbon monoxide poisoning. Brain damage is confirmed following [[magnetic resonance imaging|MRI]] or [[X-ray computed tomography|CAT]] scans.{{cite journal|vauthors=Devine SA, Kirkley SM, Palumbo CL, White RF |title=MRI and neuropsychological correlates of carbon monoxide exposure: a case report |journal=Environmental Health Perspectives |volume=110 |issue=10 |pages=1051–55 |date=October 2002 |pmid=12361932 |pmc=1241033 |doi=10.1289/ehp.021101051 |url=http://ehpnet1.niehs.nih.gov/members/2002/110p1051-1055devine/devine-full.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120707154535/http://ehpnet1.niehs.nih.gov/members/2002/110p1051-1055devine/devine-full.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-07 }}{{cite journal|vauthors=O'Donnell P, Buxton PJ, Pitkin A, Jarvis LJ |title=The magnetic resonance imaging appearances of the brain in acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Clinical Radiology|volume=55|issue=4|pages=273–80|date=April 2000|pmid=10767186|doi=10.1053/crad.1999.0369}} Extensive follow up and supportive treatment is often required for delayed neurological damage. Outcomes are often difficult to predict following poisoning,{{cite journal|vauthors=Seger D, Welch L |title=Carbon monoxide controversies: neuropsychologic testing, mechanism of toxicity, and hyperbaric oxygen|journal=Annals of Emergency Medicine|volume=24|issue=2|pages=242–48|date=August 1994|pmid=8037390|doi=10.1016/S0196-0644(94)70136-9}} especially people who have symptoms of [[cardiac arrest]], [[coma]], [[metabolic acidosis]], or have high carboxyhemoglobin levels. One study reported that approximately 30% of people with severe carbon monoxide poisoning will have a fatal outcome. It has been reported that electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) may increase the likelihood of delayed neuropsychiatric sequelae (DNS) after carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning.{{cite journal|last=Chiang|first=CL|author2=Tseng, MC|title=Safe use of electroconvulsive therapy in a highly suicidal survivor of carbon monoxide poisoning.|journal=Gen Hosp Psychiatry|date=27 September 2011}} == Epidemiology == {{Category see also|Deaths from carbon monoxide poisoning}} The true number of cases of carbon monoxide poisoning is unknown, since many non-lethal exposures go undetected. From the available data, carbon monoxide poisoning is the most common cause of injury and death due to poisoning worldwide.{{cite journal|author=Thom SR|title=Hyperbaric-oxygen therapy for acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=347|issue=14|pages=1105–06|date=October 2002|pmid=12362013|doi=10.1056/NEJMe020103}} Poisoning is typically more common during the winter months.{{cite journal |vauthors=Ernst A, Zibrak JD |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=The New England Journal of Medicine |volume=339 |issue=22 |pages=1603–08 |date=November 1998 |pmid=9828249 |doi=10.1056/NEJM199811263392206}}{{cite journal |author=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) |title=Deaths from motor-vehicle-related unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning—Colorado, 1996, New Mexico, 1980–1995, and United States, 1979–1992 |journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report |volume=45 |issue=47 |pages=1029–32 |date=November 1996 |pmid=8965803 |doi= |url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwR/preview/mmwrhtml/00044617.htm |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170624012603/https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00044617.htm |archivedate=2017-06-24 |df= }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Partrick M, Fiesseler F, Shih R, Riggs R, Hung O |title=Monthly variations in the diagnosis of carbon monoxide exposures in the emergency department |journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine |volume=36 |issue=3 |pages=161–67 |year=2009 |pmid=19860138}} This is due to increased domestic use of gas furnaces, gas or kerosene [[space heater]]s, and kitchen stoves during the winter months, which if faulty and/or used without adequate ventilation, may produce excessive carbon monoxide.{{cite journal |author=Heckerling PS |title=Occult carbon monoxide poisoning: a cause of winter headache |journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine |volume=5 |issue=3 |pages=201–04 |date=May 1987 |pmid=3580051 |doi= 10.1016/0735-6757(87)90320-2|url=}} Carbon monoxide detection and poisoning also increases during power outages, when electric heating and cooking appliances become inoperative and residents may temporarily resort to fuel-burning space heaters, stoves, and grills (some of which are safe only for outdoor use but nonetheless are errantly burned indoors).{{cite web|title=Department of Public Health Warns of Dangers of Carbon Monoxide Poisoning During Power Outages|url=http://www.towergenerator.com/Resources/Power_Generator_Carbon_Monoxide_Dangers/|publisher=Tower Generator|accessdate=2011-11-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426001248/http://www.towergenerator.com/Resources/Power_Generator_Carbon_Monoxide_Dangers/|archivedate=2012-04-26|df=}}{{cite web|title=Avoiding Carbon Monoxide poisoning during a power outage |url=http://www.bt.cdc.gov/disasters/psa/co.asp |publisher=CDC |accessdate=2011-11-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111212171534/http://www.bt.cdc.gov/disasters/psa/co.asp |archivedate=2011-12-12 |df= }}{{cite journal|last=Klein|first=Kelly|author2=Herzog, Perri |author3=Smolinske, Susan |author4= White, Suzanne |title=Demand for poison control center services "surged" during the 2003 blackout.|journal=Clinical Toxicology|year=2007|volume=45|issue=3|pages=248–54|doi=10.1080/15563650601031676 |pmid=17453875}} It has been estimated that more than 40,000 people per year seek medical attention for carbon monoxide poisoning in the United States.{{cite journal|author=Hampson NB|title=Emergency department visits for carbon monoxide poisoning in the Pacific Northwest|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |date=September 1998|pages=695–98|volume=16|issue=5|pmid=9752939|doi=10.1016/S0736-4679(98)00080-8}} 95% of carbon monoxide poisoning deaths in the United States are due to gas space heaters.{{cite web|url=http://www.esv.vic.gov.au/Portals/0/About%20ESV/Files/Gas%20use%20reports/2004AddendumtoOverseasandAustralianStatisticsandBenchmarksforCustomerGasSafetyIncidents.pdf|title=2004 Addendum to Overseas and Australian Statistics and Benchmarks for Customer Gas Safety Incidents|publisher=Office of Gas Safety, Victoria|year=2004|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924002528/http://www.esv.vic.gov.au/Portals/0/About%20ESV/Files/Gas%20use%20reports/2004AddendumtoOverseasandAustralianStatisticsandBenchmarksforCustomerGasSafetyIncidents.pdf|archivedate=2015-09-24|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.scer.gov.au/files/2012/03/EMR2-QRA-Final.pdf |title=The risk of carbon monoxide poisoning from domestic gas appliances |work=Report to the Department of Resources, Energy and Tourism |date=Feb 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150312065135/http://www.scer.gov.au/files/2012/03/EMR2-QRA-Final.pdf |archivedate=2015-03-12 |df= }} In many industrialized countries carbon monoxide is the cause of more than 50% of fatal poisonings. In the United States, approximately 200 people die each year from carbon monoxide poisoning associated with home fuel-burning heating equipment.{{cite web|title=Carbon Monoxide Detectors Can Save Lives: CPSC Document #5010|publisher=US Consumer Product Safety Commission|url=http://www.cpsc.gov/CPSCPUB/PUBS/5010.html|accessdate=2009-04-30|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090409030219/http://www.cpsc.gov/CPSCPUB/PUBS/5010.html |archivedate=2009-04-09}} Carbon monoxide poisoning contributes to the approximately 5613 smoke inhalation deaths each year in the United States.{{cite journal|vauthors=Cobb N, Etzel RA|title=Unintentional carbon monoxide-related deaths in the United States, 1979 through 1988|journal=JAMA|volume=266|issue=5|pages=659–63|date=August 7, 1991|pmid=1712865|url=http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/266/5/659|doi=10.1001/jama.266.5.659|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080921102448/http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/266/5/659|archivedate=September 21, 2008|df=}} The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] reports, "Each year, more than 500 Americans die from unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning, and more than 2,000 commit suicide by intentionally poisoning themselves."{{cite web|title=Carbon Monoxide poisoning fact sheet|publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|date=July 2006|url=https://www.cdc.gov/co/pdfs/faqs.pdf|format=pdf|doi=|accessdate=2008-12-16|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218085439/http://www.cdc.gov/co/pdfs/faqs.pdf|archivedate=2008-12-18|df=}} For the 10-year period from 1979 to 1988, 56,133 deaths from carbon monoxide poisoning occurred in the United States, with 25,889 of those being suicides, leaving 30,244 unintentional deaths. A report from [[New Zealand]] showed that 206 people died from carbon monoxide poisoning in the years of 2001 and 2002. In total carbon monoxide poisoning was responsible for 43.9% of deaths by poisoning in that country.{{cite journal|vauthors=McDowell R, Fowles J, Phillips D|title=Deaths from poisoning in New Zealand: 2001–2002|journal=[[The New Zealand Medical Journal]]|volume=118|issue=1225|page=U1725|date=November 2005|pmid=16286939|url=http://www.nzmj.com/journal/118-1225/1725/|format=Free full text|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110714220921/http://www.nzmj.com/journal/118-1225/1725/|archivedate=2011-07-14|df=}} In [[South Korea]], 1,950 people had been poisoned by carbon monoxide with 254 deaths from 2001 through 2003.{{cite journal|vauthors=Song KJ, Shin SD, Cone DC |title=Socioeconomic status and severity-based incidence of poisoning: a nationwide cohort study|journal=[[Clinical Toxicology]]|volume=47|issue=8|pages=818–26|date=September 2009|pmid=19640232|doi=10.1080/15563650903158870}} A report from [[Jerusalem]] showed 3.53 per 100,000 people were poisoned annually from 2001 through 2006.{{cite journal|vauthors=Salameh S, Amitai Y, Antopolsky M, Rott D, Stalnicowicz R |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning in Jerusalem: epidemiology and risk factors|journal=Clinical Toxicology|volume=47|issue=2|pages=137–41|date=February 2009|pmid=18720104|doi=10.1080/15563650801986711}} In [[Hubei]], China, 218 deaths from poisoning were reported over a 10-year period with 16.5% being from carbon monoxide exposure.{{cite journal |vauthors=Liu Q, Zhou L, Zheng N, Zhuo L, Liu Y, Liu L |title=Poisoning deaths in China: type and prevalence detected at the Tongji Forensic Medical Center in Hubei |journal=Forensic Science International |volume=193 |issue=1–3 |pages=88–94 |date=December 2009 |pmid=19854011 |doi=10.1016/j.forsciint.2009.09.013}} ==History== The earliest description of carbon monoxide poisoning dates to at least 200 BC by [[Aristotle]]. Documented cases of carbon monoxide being used as a [[Suicide methods#Carbon monoxide|method of suicide]] date to at least 100 BC in [[ancient Rome]].{{cite book|last1=Penney|first1=David G.|title=Carbon Monoxide Poisoning|date=2007|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0849384189|page=754|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=793KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA754|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910172025/https://books.google.com/books?id=793KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA754|archivedate=2017-09-10|df=}} In the AD 350s, the Roman emperor [[Julian (emperor)|Julian]] suffered from carbon monoxide poisoning in Paris, and later described it in his work ''Misopogon'': "though the winter weather prevailed and continually increased in severity, even so I did not allow my servants to heat the house, because I was afraid of drawing out the dampness in the walls; but I ordered them to carry in fire that had burned down and to place in the room a very moderate number of hot coals. But the coals, though there were not very many of them, brought out from the walls quantities of steam and this made me fall asleep. And since my head was filled with the fumes I was almost choked. Then I was carried outside."Julian, ''Misopogon'' 341C-D This misunderstanding of the causes of carbon monoxide poisoning may have caused the death of Julian's successor, [[Jovian (emperor)|Jovian]]. [[John Scott Haldane]] identified carbon monoxide as the lethal constituent of [[afterdamp]], the gas created by [[combustion]], after examining many bodies of miners killed in pit explosions. Their skin was coloured cherry-pink from [[carboxyhaemoglobin]], the stable compound formed in the blood by reaction with the gas. As a result of his research, he was able to design respirators for rescue workers. He tested the effect of carbon monoxide on his own body in a closed chamber, describing the results of his slow poisoning. In the late 1890s, he introduced the use of small animals for miners to detect dangerous levels of carbon monoxide underground, either white mice or canaries. With a faster metabolism, they showed the effects of poisoning before gas levels became critical for the workers, and so gave an early warning of the problem. The [[canary in a coal mine|canary]] in British pits was replaced in 1986 by the electronic gas detector. As part of the [[Holocaust]] during [[World War II]], German [[Nazi]]s used [[gas van]]s at [[Chelmno extermination camp]] and elsewhere to kill an estimated over 700,000 prisoners by carbon monoxide poisoning. This method was also used in the gas chambers of several [[extermination camp|death camps]] such as [[Treblinka]], [[Sobibor]] and [[Belzec]]. Gassing with carbon monoxide started in [[action T4]], the programme developed by the Nazis in Germany to murder the mentally ill and [[disabled people]] before the war started in earnest. The gas was supplied by [[IG Farben]] in pressurized cylinders and fed by tubes into the gas chambers built at various mental hospitals, such as [[Hartheim Euthanasia Centre]]. Many key personnel were recruited from the T4 programme to murder much larger numbers of people in the gas vans and the special [[gas chamber]]s used in the [[death camp]]s such as [[Treblinka]]. [[Exhaust fumes]] from tank engines for example, were used to supply the gas to the chambers.{{cite book|title=Dictionary of Genocide|vauthors=Totten S, Bartrop P, Markusen E|year=2007|publisher=Greenwood|pages=129, 156|url=https://books.google.com/?id=rgGA91skoP4C&lpg=PA156&dq=nazi%20carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&pg=PA156#v=onepage&q=carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&f=false|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130526000146/http://books.google.com/books?id=rgGA91skoP4C&lpg=PA156&ots=S8jhBY6NxB&dq=nazi%20carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&pg=PA156#v=onepage&q=carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&f=false|archivedate=2013-05-26|df=|isbn=978-0313346422}} The use of oxygen as treatment began in 1868. The use of hyperbaric oxygen in rats following poisoning was studied by Haldane in 1895 while its use in humans began in the 1960s. ==Research== Carbon monoxide is produced naturally by the body as a byproduct of converting [[protoporphyrin]] into [[bilirubin]]. This carbon monoxide also combines with hemoglobin to make carboxyhemoglobin, but not at toxic levels. Small amounts of CO are beneficial and enzymes exist that produce it at times of oxidative stress. Drugs are being developed to introduce small amounts of CO during certain kinds of surgery, these drugs are called [[carbon monoxide-releasing molecules]].{{cite journal|last1=Foresti|first1=R|last2=Bani-Hani|first2=MG|last3=Motterlini|first3=R|title=Use of carbon monoxide as a therapeutic agent: promises and challenges.|journal=Intensive Care Medicine|date=April 2008|volume=34|issue=4|pages=649–58|pmid=18286265|doi=10.1007/s00134-008-1011-1}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Medical resources | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = {{ICD10|T|58}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|986}} | eMedicineSubj = article | eMedicineTopic = 819987 | MeshID = D002249 }} * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/co-comp/ Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) – Carbon Monoxide – NIOSH Workplace Safety and Health Topic] * International Programme on Chemical Safety (1999). [http://www.who.int/ipcs/publications/ehc/ehc_213/en/ Carbon Monoxide], Environmental Health Criteria 213, Geneva: WHO {{Poisoning and toxicity}} {{good article}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Carbon Monoxide Poisoning}} [[Category:Carbon monoxide|Poisoning]] [[Category:Accidents]] [[Category:Industrial hygiene]] [[Category:Medical emergencies]] [[Category:Natural gas safety]] [[Category:Suicide methods]] [[Category:Toxic effects of substances chiefly nonmedicinal as to source]] [[Category:RTT]] [[Category:RTTEM]]
