{{multiple issues| {{essay-like|date=December 2017}} {{lead rewrite|date=December 2017}} {{original research|date=December 2017}} {{tone|date=December 2017}} {{Orphan|date=March 2018}} }}
'''Human response to [[disaster]]s''' has been recorded throughout human history.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} In ancient times disasters were often perceived as a result of a deity, divine being, or spiritual creature showing their displeasure over human behavior.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} This later changed as humans began to see disasters as natural events that caused physical destruction and social chaos to individuals, communities, and societies as opposed to responses to human actions.
The term "disaster myth" has been created to describe the belief that people will behave in an irrational, uncontrolled, and even extreme manner outside of normal and accepted social standards despite evidence that proponents state prove otherwise.<ref>John Drury, David Novelli, and Clifford Stott, “Psychological disaster myths in the perception and management of mass emergencies: Psychological disaster myths,” ''Journal of Applied Social Psychology'', 43 (2013): 2259.</ref><ref>Lewis Aptekar, ''Environmental Disasters in Global Perspective'' (New York: G.K. Hall & Co., 1994), 2-3.</ref> Proponents of the term further state that people will only act irrationally in the direst of circumstances when terrible danger is imminent and no avenue of escape appears available. They argue that these disaster myths cause a negative impact when they cause people, officials, and disaster-relief organizations to make detrimental or incorrect [[disaster response|disaster planning and response]] decisions.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 67.</ref>
== Panic/Scared == One commonly held disaster myth is that people develop an insurmountable, illogical fear in the face of a [[disaster]]. In turn, this fear becomes infectious, spreads to others, and causes people to flee without thinking and in a chaotic manner that could hurt those around them.<ref>Drury, Novelli, and Stott, 2259.</ref>
In fact, just the opposite can be expected in most cases.<ref>Aptekar, 5.</ref> Even when experiencing the increased stress from an [[earthquake]], since they arrive unannounced and it is not known when the aftershocks will end, people continue to act rationally.<ref>Ibid, 3.</ref> Not only do few people panic, most are unwilling to participate in an organized evacuation. Those who live in the disaster area tend to stay in place. The only ones who usually flee are the visitors, tourists, and transients.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 67.</ref> [[Disaster]]s also draw people to the area. Some want to help while others just want to see the destruction.<ref>Aptekar, 5.</ref>
The general public and organizations involved in [[emergency management|emergency planning, management, and response]] all tend to accept this disaster myth as reality.<ref>Nogami and Yoshida, S191-S192.</ref> [[Panic]]king can cause harm to others if people flee without thought. Staying put can be even worse since the people are not getting away from the [[disaster|disaster’s]] damage and destruction. When necessary, people should evacuate in an orderly manner to avoid the [[disaster]]. It also provides an opportunity to help others evacuate who may need assistance.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 68.</ref> The myth of [[panic]] can cause officials to be cautious when issuing public bulletins. By not wanting to instigate or amplify the believed [[panic]], officials may wait too long to provide the information on which the populace should act.<ref>Aptekar, 6.</ref> To avoid contributing to or increasing the level of this mythical [[panic]], officials have also chosen to not share information about preparations for some types of [[disaster]]s (e.g. [[chemical warfare|chemical]] and [[biological warfare|biological]] attacks).<ref>Drury, Novelli, and Stott, 2260.</ref>
The antithesis of the panic myth was seen with Orson Welles’ [[The War of the Worlds]] radio broadcast in 1938, the [[Cocoanut Grove fire|1942 Cocoanut Grove nightclub fire]], and as [[Hurricane Carla]] approached the Gulf Coast areas of Texas and Louisiana in 1961.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 67-68.</ref> Rational behavior also dominated after [[earthquake]]s in Europe, North and South America, and Asia.<ref>Aptekar, 3.</ref> Despite many reports of widespread [[panic]], evidence later proved otherwise.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 67.</ref> The myth of [[panic]] affecting the official warnings of authorities has been seen in Mexico when the Rio Grande River flooded, in Italy during the [[flood]]ing of the city of Florence, and after a volcanic eruption in Japan.<ref>Aptekar, 6.</ref> In the instances when authorities chose to send the military instead of humanitarian organizations in response to [[Hurricane Katrina]], it was in some part to help manage and control the perceived [[panic]] among the population.<ref>Drury, Novelli, and Stott, 2260.</ref>
== Shock == Many people believe those who experience a [[disaster]] firsthand experience emotional trauma that has both immediate and lasting effects.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 68.</ref> It is thought the initial devastation of the [[disaster]] leaves people too fragile and in [[Acute stress reaction|shock]].<ref>Drury, Novelli, and Stott, 2259.</ref> As such, they are unable to cope with their situation or participate in recovery efforts. They are consequently dependent on assistance from outside relief agencies.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 68.</ref>
Only in a small minority of cases does this myth turn out to be true. And many times, the experienced shock is short-lived. What in fact happens in most cases is people react immediately to the [[disaster]] and its effects.<ref>Ibid.</ref> The [[disaster]] can also be a jolt of energy which drives people to respond to the emergency.<ref>Claude de Ville de Goyet, “Stop Propagating Disaster Myths,” ''The Lancet'', 356, no. 9231 (August 26, 2000): 763.</ref> Those who went through the [[disaster]] are the first engaged in relief and rescue efforts before any outside agency. They come together along familiar lines such as family and friends and then move as needed to a larger scale involving groups with which they associate (e.g. churches). If the familiar cannot be contacted or they are unable to respond, only then do most people look toward the faceless law enforcement, welfare, and relief organizations for assistance. People will also seek help from outside the familiar when special equipment or medical skills are required.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 68.</ref>
The myth of widespread shock leads outside relief organizations to plan their efforts as if they are the only ones who will be providing assistance. This may create a disconnected rather than complementary relationship between them and the local agencies. Additionally, the feeling on the part of the survivors that they do not need to rely on outsiders coupled with the relief organizations believing they are saviors creates a wall between the two which in turn inhibits communication, coordination, and effective relief and recovery efforts.<ref>Ibid.</ref>
People’s reliance on self and the well-known was seen in a variety of disaster types such as the [[1953 Flint-Beecher tornado|1953 tornado in Flint-Beecher, Michigan]], the 1955 flood of Marysville and Yuba City, California, [[Hurricane Audrey]] in 1957, [[Hurricane Carla]] in 1961, [[Hurricane Betsy]] in 1965, and the [[1971 San Fernando earthquake|1971 earthquake in San Fernando, California]].<ref>Ibid.</ref> Both in [[1985 Mexico City earthquake|Mexico City in 1985]] and in [[1999 Izmit earthquake|Turkey in 1999]], thousands of local residents banded together to search for fellow victims in the earthquake wreckage.<ref>de Goyet, 763.</ref> Neighbors performed more than half of the rescue activities after the [[Great Hanshin earthquake|Great Hanshin-Awaji earthquake]] hit Kobe City, Japan in 1995.<ref>Nogami and Yoshida, S192.</ref>
== Assistance == People believe the population impacted by a [[disaster]] are unable to do anything about their situation so are standing by just waiting for the saviors from afar to swoop in with the solution to all of their suffering. Not only that, relief organizations often think the aid must be provided immediately. This myth is especially pervasive when the [[disaster]] strikes a third-world country and it is a “superior” western country coming to the rescue.<ref>de Goyet, 762-763.</ref>
While relief organizations with emergency managers, medical teams, and the like do offer assistance after a [[disaster]], most people are actually saved by other survivors and local authorities, agencies, and organizations.<ref>Ibid, 762.</ref>
Because of this myth, more supplies are often sent than the disaster area typically needs. In addition to excess quantity, much of the supplies end up being of little to no use.<ref>Nogami and Yoshida, S193.</ref> Relief organizations often do not wait for an assessment of the disaster area and an identification of needs which can be provided by local officials or performed by themselves. As a consequence, money is often wasted on sending unneeded teams of experts or supplies when local authorities and victims would benefit more if that same money was allocated towards providing resources that filled gaps and complemented their efforts. Donors compound the issue by donating used clothing, household items, and the like.<ref>de Goyet, 763.</ref> With too many supplies on-hand or in possession of supplies they cannot use, local officials are forced to waste manpower and resources on disposing of them.<ref>Nogami and Yoshida, S193.</ref> Instead of providing unwanted and unrequested goods, organizations and donors should send money which can be more easily applied to fulfilling local needs.<ref>de Goyet, 763.</ref>
An example of this myth’s impact was seen following the [[1993 Hokkaidō earthquake]] as authorities were forced to spend 1.2 million in U.S. dollars on the removal of unnecessary relief supplies.<ref>Nogami and Yoshida, S193.</ref>
== Resources == Outside rescue, relief, and recovery agencies almost always miscalculate the amount of available resources for basic needs that are available locally in the aftermath of a [[disaster]]. They believe there are not enough materiel, supplies, and personnel for the initial response.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 69.</ref>
In fact, there are usually enough supplies to last several weeks. Enough food can normally be found in stores, warehouses, and people’s homes. Clothing is rarely needed. Medical supplies reside in hospitals, warehouses, or nearby communities. Hospitals as well as police and fire departments often transition to 24-hour operations. And no evidence is available that proves the unfound belief that key personnel will leave their posts to go attend to their families and friends.<ref>Ibid.</ref>
Relief agencies tend to believe they must act immediately rather than assess the situation first. As a result, they often provide supplies when there is already enough on-site for the immediate future.<ref>Ibid.</ref>
== Crime == The prevalence of [[looting]] in the wake of [[disaster]]s is another common myth.<ref>Ibid.</ref> It is thought that [[disaster]]s provide cover for criminal activity.<ref>Drury, Novelli, and Stott, 2259.</ref> In this scenario, people take advantage of law enforcement and other agencies responsible for maintaining the peace, safety, and security being occupied with disaster response and relief efforts.<ref>Aptekar, 4.</ref> People believe criminals will use the [[disaster]] as an opportunity to loot due to a prevalence of evacuated, abandoned, and unguarded homes and stores.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 69.</ref>
While [[looting]] can occur, they are always isolated incidents. And much reported [[looting]] is either entirely false or, at worst, desperate survivors scavenging for necessities.<ref>Ibid.</ref>
But because people believe [[looting]] happens, they frequently refuse to leave despite the disaster’s destruction and damage in order to protect their homes and property.<ref>Aptekar, 5.</ref> When no [[looting]] occurs, people tend to believe it is because enough security was in place to prevent it rather than looters did not exist in the first place.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 69.</ref> Also, officials who believe in this myth end up assigning personnel to a protection role rather than to a much more critical rescue, relief, or logistics support function.<ref>de Goyet, 763.</ref>
The lack of connection between [[disaster]]s and [[looting]] was seen in the rates for theft and burglaries actually falling after [[Hurricane Betsy]] in 1965.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 69.</ref> This myth’s impact was also seen outside the United States as evidenced by many Guatemalans staying after the [[1976 Guatemala earthquake|1976 earthquake]] out of fear of having their animals, homes, and possessions stolen.<ref>Aptekar, 5.</ref>
== Morale == People tend to believe that survivors are extremely negative after a disaster and need to assurance that the outside world cares and the future is bright for themselves and their community.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 70.</ref>
In fact, people are most often optimistic and have very high [[morale]] in a disaster’s aftermath. They frequently subordinate any personal feelings of loss and suffering in order to apply themselves to providing food, shelter, and other services to those in need. Their motivation to help one another boosts the sense of community and togetherness.<ref>Ibid, 69-70.</ref>
Because of the myth, dignitaries and officials feel the need to come to the disaster area to reassure the survivors. They often make promises of aid that either are not kept or do not happen in a timely manner. This can cause survivors to resent outsiders. This resentment in turn can prevent the survivors from asking for needed skills and resources that the outsiders can in fact provide.<ref>Ibid, 70.</ref>
== Disease == When a [[disaster]] results in deaths, especially in large quantities, people often believe they are at considerable risk of catching a [[disease]] from them.<ref>de Goyet, 762.</ref> They also believe [[epidemic|disease epidemics]] develop in the wake of [[disaster]]s.<ref>Aptekar, 5.</ref>
The fact that they died from the [[disaster]] does not make them a risk for spreading [[disease]]s. If a body does carry a [[infection|communicable disease]], the person already had it when he or she was alive. The fact that the body is now stationary and will remain in one place makes it less of a risk than prior to death.<ref>de Goyet, 762.</ref> And an [[epidemic]] would happen only if either of two circumstances exist: 1) the [[disaster]] brings [[disease]] with it for which the people are not immune or 2) the disaster’s effects lead to [[malnutrition]], the [[malnutrition]] increases susceptibility to [[disease]], and finally, a large number of people contract the [[disease]].<ref>Aptekar, 5.</ref>
The belief in the myth can result in the hurried disposal of the bodies without proper identification, burial, or involvement by the next of kin. This can add to the suffering of survivors because they were not allowed to properly care for their loved ones. In addition to the personal toll, needlessly disposing of dead bodies can divert personnel and supplies from other areas where at that time they are needed more (e.g. involved in actions that benefit those still living).<ref>de Goyet, 762.</ref> Fear or rumor of an [[epidemic]] can also cause relief organizations to provide medicines, resources, and other aid for a problem that does not exist.<ref>Aptekar, 5.</ref>
This myth has been repeated many times such as in the [[1972 Nicaragua earthquake|1972 earthquake in Managua, Nicaragua]], [[Hurricane Mitch]] in 1998, the [[1999 Izmit earthquake|1999 earthquake in Turkey]], and the [[2000 Mozambique flood|2000 flooding in Mozambique]].<ref>de Goyet, 762.</ref> Additionally, rumors of [[hepatitis]], [[measles]], [[dysentery]], and [[typhus]] that were later proven to be false followed the [[1976 Guatemala earthquake|1976 earthquake in Guatemala]].<ref>Aptekar, 5.</ref>
== Perpetuation of myths == [[File:Hydra1.gif|thumb|Myths Live On]]
=== By people === People who have experienced a [[disaster]] often believe the dramatic accounts of their own suffering. It allows them to pass off their actions as atypical and heroic. In the process of telling others about their involvement, the mythic component of their story is spread along with the reality.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 70.</ref>
Disaster survivors tend to worry about [[looting]]. Their increased anxiety can cause them to spread reports whether they definitely know of any or not. While most people who are asked admit to not having personally witnessed or experienced [[looting]], many claim of being aware of it elsewhere. The belief in [[looting]] can make people jump to the conclusion that looting was the cause of items going missing before considering the [[disaster]] may have moved, buried, or destroyed them.<ref>Ibid, 69.</ref>
=== By organizations === Government agencies, civilian organizations, and [[first responder]]s all believe to some extent in disaster myths.<ref>Drury, Novelli, and Stott, 2266.</ref> When this happens, the myths in turn are often included in their [[disaster response|planning and response]] to [[disaster]]s, victims, and survivors. And practices based even partially on disaster myths are not only likely to result in inappropriate or inefficient relief and response actions, they can also help to perpetuate the myths thereby affecting people and property in the next [[disaster]].<ref>Ibid, 2269.</ref>
An example of how organizations can perpetuate disaster myths takes place in the days following a [[disaster]] and up until official numbers are compiled. During this time, officials from emergency, relief, rescue, and welfare organizations can overestimate the loss of life and destruction of property. This sheds a more positive light on their organizations since they can point to effective emergency procedures and local heroism as the reason their figures turned out to be higher than the actual numbers. If their calculations end up being lower than the official figures, they might be blamed for incompetence and inefficiency.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 70.</ref>
Although the inability to cope by a disaster-site’s community and people is a myth, it continues to be believed. One reason is the justification relief agencies give while promoting the assistance they provide. They feel they are needed because they believe facilities such as hospitals, police and fire departments, and other local first responders do not have the capacity to meet the sheer demand from a disaster. And if their efforts do not go as planned, they often point to survivors’ irrationality rather than reassess the assumptions on which they developed their relief plans.<ref>Ibid, 68-69.</ref>
Local, regional, and national officials make up a primary source of information for the media. In the self-imposed small window the media has to get out the latest details of the disaster, fact-checking sometimes suffers and they rely solely on the officials' accuracy.<ref>Ibid, 70.</ref> Consequently, officials substantially influence the media's portrayal and what viewers, listeners, and readers see. An example of this is seen in officials highlighting the positives within their own organization's efforts while downplaying the information from and activities by unofficial groups and sources.<ref>James D. Goltz, "Are the News Media Responsible for the Disaster Myths? A Content Analysis of Emergency Response Imagery," ''International Journal of Mass Emergencies and Disasters 2'', no. 3 (1984): 365-366.</ref>
When asked by the media, law enforcement officials frequently say they are taking sufficient action to prevent [[looting]] even if they have taken no action on the issue. If the norm happens and little to no [[looting]] occurs, they may be credited for the absence of crime. But if the exception to the rule happens, they do not want to be blamed for not protecting against the [[looting]]. Whether it is true or not, people believe local law enforcement is out keeping the area secure from looters and the myth continues to propagate.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 69.</ref>
=== By media === Many myths are perpetuated by the mass media to include newspapers, television, radio, and internet news.<ref>Nogami and Yoshida, S201.</ref> This is largely due to the way they portray [[disaster]]s. In fact, most people base their opinions and beliefs regarding [[disaster]]s and survivor behavior on what they see in the media. The media strives to keep their viewers’ and readers’ attention for as long as possible. Drama and destruction is interesting and compelling; most of everything else is secondary.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 70.</ref> For the most part, the media, regardless of country, takes a fairly standard approach to disaster coverage and reporting. Immediately after the [[disaster]], they rely on statistics of destruction and damage followed by stories of victims and those providing the rescue and relief.<ref>Aptekar, 129-130.</ref> The media repeatedly moves away from discussing the [[disaster]] as a whole to focusing on individual parts and the drama involved in them.<ref>Ibid, 130.</ref> As a result of its manner in covering [[disaster]]s, the media may capture only pieces instead of the entire event while emphasizing the unusually heroic or unusually tragic incidents.<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 70.</ref>
A main focus of media coverage centers on [[emergency management]] organizations performing rescue and relief actions in the disaster area.<ref>Goltz, 364-365.</ref> The media frequently portrays international relief teams as angels saving the victims from the disaster's destruction while simultaneously implying the local officials are negligent, inept, or corrupt.<ref>de Goyet, 762.</ref> Within this backdrop, the portrayal of a breakdown in society and social behavior is more likely to appear in coverage of [[disaster]]s occurring outside the [[United States]].<ref>Goltz, 365.</ref> An example of this type of portrayal that helps perpetuate disaster myths involves the frequent reports of people panicking in both small and large numbers to the point of fleeing when faced by an oncoming [[disaster]] such as a [[hurricane]].<ref>Quarantelli and Dynes, 67.</ref>
Additionally, when the international media noticed few stories of [[looting]] coming out of [[Japan]] following the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|Great East Japan Disaster in 2011]], they generally remarked on how well the Japanese people behave. By believing in this myth, they assumed the Japanese showed more behavioral control than other societies rather than understanding it rarely happens in association with any [[disaster]].<ref>Nogami and Yoshida, S192.</ref>
== References == {{Ibid|date=March 2018}} <references />

''The Lancet'', 356, no. 9231 (August 26, 2000): 762-764. # Drury, John, David Novelli, and Clifford Stott. “Psychological disaster myths in the perception and management of mass emergencies: Psychological disaster myths.” ''Journal of Applied Social Psychology'', 43 (2013): 2259-2270. # Goltz, James D. "Are the News Media Responsible for the Disaster Myths? A Content Analysis of Emergency Response Imagery." ''International Journal of Mass Emergencies and Disasters 2'', no. 3 (1984): 345-368. # Nogami, Tatsuya, and Fujio Yoshida. "Disaster myths after the Great East Japan Disaster and the effects of information sources on belief in such myths." ''Disasters'' 38, no. Supp 2 (2014): S190-S205. # Quarantelli, E.L., and Russel R. Dynes. “When Disaster Strikes (It Isn’t Much Like What You’ve Heard & Read About).” ''Psychology Today'' (February 1972): 67-70.
[[Category:Disasters]]

The term '''international crisis''' is widespread term without a single common definition.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Acuto|first=Michele|title=Diplomats in Crisis|journal=Diplomacy & Statecraft|date=7 September 2011|volume=online|doi=10.1080/09592296.2011.599661|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09592296.2011.599661|accessdate=5 March 2014}}</ref> To some, it involves "a sequence of interactions between the governments of two or more sovereign states in severe conflict, short of actual war, but involving the perception of a dangerously high probability of [[war]]".<ref>Snyder, Glenn H. and Diesing, Paul: 1977. Conflict Among Nations: Bargaining, Decision Making and System Structure in International Crises. defines an international crisis</ref>
==Types== Lebow gives a breakdown of three types of international crises: * '''Justification of Hostilities'''.<ref>Lebow, Richard N.:1981. Between Peace and War: The Nature of International Crisis.</ref> One of the nations decides, before the crisis starts, to go to [[war]] and constructs a crisis to justify it. The pattern of justification is almost always the same: Rouse public opinion, make impossible demands, try to legitimize the demands, deny your real intentions then employ the rejection of the demands as a reason for war. A recent example, commonly employed by [[Public image of George W. Bush|critics of George W. Bush]], is the [[Iraq disarmament crisis]], which precipitated the [[Iraq War]]. * '''Spinoff Crisis'''. The nations are involved in a war or crisis with another nation or nations and this precipitates another crisis, e.g. the [[RMS Lusitania|Lusitania]] incident in 1915. * '''Brinkmanship'''. Intentionally forcing a crisis to get the other side to back down. The [[Cuban Missile Crisis]] of 1962 is a well-known example of [[brinkmanship]].
With the exception of a justification of hostilities, the study of international crises assumes that neither side actually wants to go to war, but must be visibly prepared to do so. In the words of [[Groucho Marx]], "Always be sincere, even if you don't mean it".
==Strategies== George's book presents an overview of the process and conflicting goals of [[crisis management]] as well as many examples.<ref>George, Alexander L (ed): 1991. Avoiding War: Problems of Crisis Management.</ref> He discusses a number of strategies, including:
===Offensive strategies=== *[[blackmail]] *limited and reversible response *controlled pressure *[[attrition warfare|attrition]] *[[fait accompli]]
===Defensive strategies=== *[[coercion]] *limited [[conflict escalation|escalation]] *[[tit-for-tat]] *test of capabilities *"drawing a line" * Buying time strategy * Conveying commitment and resolve to avoid miscalculation by the adversary
==List of defused crises== International crises tend to result in war, almost by definition; they are then remembered best not as crises but as [[Casus belli|causes of wars]]. For information on international crises that resulted immediately in war, see [[List of wars]]. <!-- 2008 South Ossetia war (C[ommonly]K[nown]A[s] Russo-Georgian war) belongs to aforementioned [[list of wars]] (or, more precisely, to [[List of wars 2003–10]]) rather than to "ongoing crises" below --> Given the above, some of the crises that are best-known ''as crises'' were defused. The following crises did not immediately provoke large-scale violence, but set of anger in countries:
* [[War in sight crisis]] (1875) * [[Anglo-Portuguese Crisis]] (1889–1890) * [[Venezuelan crisis of 1895]], between Venezuela and the United Kingdom * [[Fashoda Incident]] (1898–1899) *[[Venezuelan crisis of 1902–03]], between Venezuela and Britain, Germany and Italy * [[First Moroccan Crisis]] (1904–1906) *[[Dutch–Venezuelan crisis of 1908]], between Venezuela and the Netherlands * [[Bosnian crisis]] (1908–1909) * [[Agadir Crisis]] (1911) * [[Åland crisis]] (1916–1920) * [[Remilitarization of the Rhineland]] (1936) * [[Anschluss]] (1938) * [[May Crisis 1938|May Crisis]] (1938) * [[Munich Agreement|Sudetenland Crisis]] (1938) * [[Iran crisis of 1946|Iran crisis]] (1946–1947) * [[Berlin Blockade]] (1948–1949) * [[Cuban Missile Crisis]] (1962) * [[USS Pueblo (AGER-2)|''Pueblo'' incident]] (1968) * [[Sino-Soviet border conflict#Border conflict of 1969|Damansky Island Crisis]] (1969) * [[1973 Chilean coup]] * [[Axe Murder Incident]] (1976) * [[Beagle conflict]] (1978) * [[Iran hostage crisis]] (1979) * [[:es:Crisis de la Corbeta Caldas|Caldas' crisis]] (1987) * [[Able Archer 83]] (1983) * [[September 11 attacks]] (2001) * [[2001 Indian Parliament attack]] (2001) * [[November 2008 Mumbai attacks]] (2008) * [[Korean crisis]] (2013) {{Expand list|date=August 2008}}
==Ongoing crises== *[[World hunger]] *[[Poverty]] *[[Global warming]] *[[North Korea and weapons of mass destruction]] *[[Islamic terrorism]] *[[Syrian Civil War]] *[[2017–18 Qatar diplomatic crisis]] (2017-ongoing)
==See also== *[[Diplomacy]] *[[International relations]] *[[The UN]] *[[World Bank]] *[[G-20]] *[[Negotiation]] *[[Crisis]] *[[Crisis management]]
==References== {{Reflist}} # Snyder, Glenn H. and Diesing, Paul: 1977. Conflict Among Nations: Bargaining, Decision Making and System Structure in International Crises. {{ISBN|0-691-05664-1}} # Lebow, Richard N.:1981. Between Peace and War: The Nature of International Crisis. {{ISBN|0-8018-2311-0}} #George, Alexander L (ed): 1991. Avoiding War: Problems of Crisis Management. {{ISBN|0-8133-1232-9}}

<!-- notability|Biographies|date=August 2014 --> {{Infobox person |name = Jennifer Gilbert |image = File:Jennifer Gilbert.jpg |birth_date = {{birth_date and age|1968|12|24}} |birth_place = |death_place = |occupation = Entrepreneur, TV personality |alma_mater = [[University of Vermont]] |known_for = Founder of ''Save the Date'' |citizenship = United States |networth = |residence = [[New York City|Greater New York City]] |salary = |spouse = |children = }}
'''Jennifer Gilbert''' (born December 24, 1968) is an American [[entrepreneur]] and [[TV personality]]. She is the founder and chief visionary officer of ''Save the Date'', a [[New York City|New York]]–based special events company. She was named one of the ''entrepreneurs of the year'' by [[Ernst & Young]] for her event planning company, ''Save the Date'' in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|title=Enchanted Evenings: New York's Top Event Planners|author=Polster, Allison|url=https://gotham-magazine.com/new-yorks-top-event-planners|website=[[Gotham (magazine)|gotham-magazine.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> She has also appeared on the TV series ''[[Real Housewives of New York City]]''.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ernst, Amanda|title=Jennifer Gilbert Reacts To Her Hilarious ‘Real Housewives’ Debut|url=http://www.crushable.com/2010/05/07/entertainment/exclusive-jennifer-gilbert-reacts-to-her-hilarious-real-housewives-debut/|date=May 7, 2010|website=crushable.com|publisher=[[Defy Media]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref name="ref1">{{cite news|author=Palmer, Amy|title=When a 20-Year-Old Secret is Revealed: 'I Refuse to Be A Victim'|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/amy-palmer/jennifer-gilbert_b_1519270.html|date=May 7, 2010|work=[[HuffPost]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Cruz, Clarissa|author2=Bailly, Jenny|url=http://www.oprah.com/style/female-authors-model-summer-fashion-under-100|title=7 Authors Model Summer's Most Sizzling (Under-$100!) Outfits|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
==Early life and career== Gilbert graduated from the [[University of Vermont]] in 1990 and received a [[Bachelor of Science]] in [[Consumer market|Consumer Marketing]] with a minor in Business. After graduation Gilbert moved to [[New York City]]. In 1991, at the age of 22, a stranger attacked her, stabbing her 37 times with a screwdriver before leaving her for dead.<ref name="ref1"/><ref>{{cite web|title=The Scars You Don't See|url=http://www.marieclaire.com/world-reports/jennifer-gilbert-attack|website=[[Marie Claire|marieclaire.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jennifer-gilbert/finally-an-anniversary-to_b_10228850.html|title=Finally, an Anniversary to Celebrate|author=Gilbert, Jennifer|date=June 2, 2016|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Abbasi, Jennifer|url=https://www.success.com/article/jennifer-gilbert-woman-warrior|title=Jennifer Gilbert: Woman Warrior|date=April 11, 2014|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
After recovering, she decided to become an [[Event planning|event planner]] and started ''Save the Date'', a New York based [[event planning]] company, in 1994.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inc.com/magazine/201207/burt-helm/jennifer-gilbert-save-the-date-how-i-did-it.html|title='Why I Will Never Be a Victim'|date=June 28, 2012|magazine=[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=How I Rebuilt My Life After Being Attacked|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/jennifer-gilbert/how-i-rebuilt-my-life-after-attack_b_1581340.html|author=Gilbert, Jennifer|date=August 6, 2012|work=HuffPost|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> In 2010 she sued a dating company with similar name called Save the Dating, the company went off business after lawsuit.<ref>{{cite news|author=Cowles, Charlotte|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2010/04/new_housewife_jennifer_gilbert.html|title=New Housewife Jennifer Gilbert Sues New York Matchmaking Business; Gerunds Involved|work=[[New York Post]]|date=April 9, 2010|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> The company has rendered services to many notable companies including several in [[Fortune 500]] companies and has been retained by clients such as [[Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation]], [[Oprah Winfrey]] and singer [[Jewel (singer)|Jewel]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Jennifer Gilbert - Who is She|url=http://www.ladieswholaunch.com/magazine/jennifer-gilbert/1094|publisher=ladieswholaunch.com|date=May 11, 2004|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/video/277455|title=Jennifer Gilbert Bounced Back From a Near-Fatal Attack to Find Massive Business Success|author=Schultz, Erin|website=Entrepreneur|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
She is also the co-owner of Portamee, a [[baby carrier]] company.<ref>{{cite web|title=Portamee - who are WEe|url=http://www.portamee.com/who.html|publisher=portamee.com|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> She has also authored a book, ''I Never Promised You A Goodie Bag'', in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=I Never Promised You a Goodie Bag: A Memoir of a Life Through Events--the Ones You Plan and the Ones You Don't|url=https://www.amazon.com/Never-Promised-You-Goodie-Events/dp/B00B558OSO|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Jennifer Gilbert, Author Of Memoir 'I Never Promised You A Goodie Bag,' Talks Success After Violence|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/05/14/jennifer-gilbert-i-never-promised-you-a-goodie-bag_n_1516243.html|work=HuffPost|accessdate=April 26, 2018|date=May 14, 2012}}</ref> In her book, she discussed about how her life changed after being attacked at a young age and then how she got control on her life and started a successful company.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jennifer Gilbert|url=http://www.myfoxny.com/story/18441551/jennifer-gilbert|date=May 17, 2012|publisher=myfoxny.com|accessdate=May 19, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819012819/http://www.myfoxny.com/story/18441551/jennifer-gilbert |archivedate=August 19, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> She spoke at [[TEDx]] [[Barnard College|Barnard College Women]] sharing her entrepreneurial spirit and philosophy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Entrepreneurial Spirit: Jennifer Gilbert at TEDxBarnardCollegeWomen|url=http://socksonanoctopus.com/ted-talks-entrepreneurial-spirit-jennifer-gilbert/|publisher=Soccks on an Octopus|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
==TV appearances== She appeared as herself in the [[Bravo (U.S. TV channel)|Bravo's]] hit TV series ''[[Real Housewives of New York City]]'' in 2010.<ref>{{cite news|title=New 'Housewife' Jennifer Gilbert Loses Airtime, Cut From Reunion Special|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/06/03/new-housewife-jennifer-gi_0_n_598857.html|author=Rancilio, Alicia|agency=[[Associated Press|AP]]|date=February 6, 2010|work=[[HuffPost]]|accessdate=May 19, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129085209/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/06/03/new-housewife-jennifer-gi_0_n_598857.html|archivedate=November 29, 2014|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> She was the party planner for [[Jill Zarin]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Meet NYC’s new ‘Real Housewives’ set to shake up the show|url=https://nypost.com/2010/04/01/meet-nycs-new-real-housewives-set-to-shake-up-the-show/|date=April 1, 2010|publisher=[[nypost.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018|author=Eber, Hailey}}</ref>
==Personal life== In 1994, Gilbert met her husband, a [[Wall Street]] Executive, Bennett Egeth and the two were married in [[New York City]] 7 years later.
Gilbert lives in [[New York City]] with her husband, their daughter and twin boys.<ref>{{cite news|title=WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS: VOWS; Jennifer Gilbert and Bennett Egeth|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/12/01/style/weddings-celebrations-vows-jennifer-gilbert-and-bennett-egeth.html|date=December 1, 2002|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018|author=Louie, Elaine}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Infobox historical event | Event_Name = Killing of José Rodríguez | Image_Name = File:Mexican-American border at Nogales.jpg | Imagesize = 300 | Image_Alt = | Image_Caption = View of the international border from the top of the U.S. Customs port of entry facility in Nogales, Arizona (January 2007) | Thumb_Time = | AKA = | Participants = | Location = [[Nogales, Arizona]], [[United States of America|USA]]
[[Nogales, Sonora]], [[Mexico]] | Date = 10 October 2012 | Deaths = 1 | Result = [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection]] Agent Lonnie Swartz charged with murder. | URL = }} {{Campaignbox Mexican Drug War}} On 10 October 2012, at the [[Mexico–United States border]] near [[Nogales, Arizona]], [[U.S. Border Patrol]] agent Lonnie Swartz fired 16 shots at '''José Antonio Elena Rodríguez''', killing him,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/06/magazine/10-shots-across-the-border.html|title=10 Shots Across the Border|last=Binelli|first=Mark|date=2016-03-03|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2017-01-23}} on the grounds that [[Criminal rock throwing|young men threw rocks]] at him and other law enforcement agents. After the incident, the law enforcement agencies stated the Mexican civilians were trying to stop them from confiscating a shipment of contraband drugs as well as moving immigrants across the border. Rodriguez was hit 10 times by the patrol officer's shots.{{cite news|last1=Carranza|first1=Rafael|last2=O'Dell|first2=Rob|title=Border Patrol agent Lonnie Swartz found not guilty in cross-border slaying of Mexican teen|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/border-issues/2018/04/23/border-patrol-agent-lonnie-swartz-found-not-guilty-cross-border-slaying-mexican-teen/544197002/|accessdate=24 May 2018|publisher=[[The Arizona Republic]]|date=23 April 2018}}{{cite news |last=Yuhas|first=Alan|date=31 May 2015|title=Justice for José? Border shooting of Mexican teen raises constitutional issue|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/may/31/jose-antonio-us-mexico-border-shooting-constitutional-rights|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=9 October 2015}}{{cite news |last=Burnett|first=John|date=9 October 2015|title=In A First, Border Agent Indicted For Killing Mexican Teen Across Fence|url=https://www.npr.org/2015/10/09/446866267/in-a-first-border-agent-indicted-for-killing-mexican-teen-across-fence|newspaper=[[NPR]]|access-date=9 October 2015}} ==Incident== Around 11:30 p.m. on Wednesday 10 October, 2012, John Zuñiga, a police officer in [[Nogales, Arizona]], received a call reporting "suspicious activity" on International Street, a road running directly along the border. Getting to the scene, Zuñiga heard from another police officer from Nogales, Quinardo Garci, that two men carrying "bundles taped to their backs" had climbed the fence into the United States. Identifying the bundles, on the basis of similar incidents in the past, as most probably containing [[marijuana]], they called out for back up. After several [[United States Border Patrol|Border Patrol]] and [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection|Customs]] agents arrived, they saw the two men scaling the fence back into Mexico, empty-handed and with nothing on their backs. They commanded the two men to climb back down. At that time, Garcia and Zuñiga stated in their reports that they saw "rocks flying through the air"{{Cite website|title=Border agent's murder trial postponed|url=http://tucson.com/news/border-agent-s-murder-trial-postponed/article_561ac027-ef47-5d29-8d01-9c073669afff.html|format=|date=2016-01-05|author=Perla Trevizo|publisher=Arizona Daily Star|postscript=|accessdate=2016-03-21}} at the assorted agents and also heard "gunfire," although they were unable to identify its source. In the days following the incident, the [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection]] agency stated that :After verbal commands from agents to cease [assaulting the agents with rocks] were ignored, one agent then discharged his service firearm. One of the subjects appeared to have been hit. The person hit was José Antonio Elena Rodríguez, a 16-year old resident of [[Nogales, Sonora|Nogales, Mexico]]. He was unarmed, standing on the Mexican side of the border on a sidewalk on Calle Internacional street, in front of a doctor’s office, below a sign reading "Medical Emergencies" in Spanish. He was hit from behind by 10 bullets. The [[autopsy]] revealed that gunshot wounds to the head, [[lung]]s, and [[artery|arteries]] killed him. ==Trial== U.S. Border Patrol agent Lonnie Ray Swartz was charged with [[second degree murder]] for the killing of José Rodríguez. It was the first time a US law enforcement officer was brought up on charges related to a killing that took part across the US-Mexican border, despite there having been a number of similar incidents in the preceding decade.{{cite news |last=Davis|first=Charles|date=4 January 2015|title=U.S. Customs and Border Protection Has Killed Nearly 50 People in 10 Years. Most Were Unarmed.|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/120687/border-patrol-officers-get-impunity-anonymity-immigrant-killings|newspaper=[[The New Republic]]|access-date=9 October 2015}} In the trial, which began in late 2015 at the Evo A. DeConcini U.S. Courthouse, the defendant claimed he had used deadly force because Rodriguez "had been throwing rocks." Although a witness testified that Rodríguez was not throwing rocks at the law enforcement officers, evidence showed that he was, along with other youths and men. Prosecutors acknowledged that Rodríguez was throwing rocks across the border but stated "he did not deserve to die" for this.{{cite news|title=Mistrial announced for U.S. border agent linked to teenager's fatal shooting|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/mistrial-us-border-patrol-agent-lonnie-swartz-manslaughter-charges-today-2018-04-23/|accessdate=24 May 2018|publisher=CBS News|date=23 April 2018}} The U.S. Customs and Border Protection refused to release surveillance-camera footage of the incident. After the testimony by Emma Lew, the director of the medical examiner in [[Miami-Dade County]], Florida, who stated that Swartz's first shot "likely hit the boy in the middle of his back as he was running," the prosecution rested its case in the trial on 5 April 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.tucsonsentinel.com/local/report/040518_swartz_trial/swartz-trial-defense-struggles-with-first-witness-after-prosecution-rests/|title= Swartz trial: Defense struggles with first witness after prosecution rests|author=Paul Ingram|publisher=Tucson Sentinel|date=2018-04-05}} On 23 April 2018, Swartz was acquitted of the charge for second-degree murder; the jury was [[deadlock]]ed on lesser charges.{{Cite news|last1=Carranza |first1=Rafael |last2=O'Dell |first2=Rob |url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/2018/04/23/border-patrol-agent-lonnie-swartz-found-not-guilty-cross-border-slaying-mexican-teen/544197002/|title=Border Patrol agent Lonnie Swartz found not guilty in cross-border slaying of Mexican teen|work=[[The Arizona Republic]]|access-date=24 April 2018|language=en}} ==Aftermath== The judge presiding on the trial, [[Raner Collins]], declared a [[mistrial]]. The head of the Tucson union for Border Patrol officers, stated, after the jury's decision was announced, that "justice was properly served" and that the union was "pretty happy with it." After the jury's decision was reported in the news, protesters gathered outside the federal courthouse in downtown Tucson late Monday afternoon, and blocked off the intersection in front of it. Among those participating in the protest was the mother of Carlos LaMadrid, another Mexican teen who, in 2011, had been shot and killed by Border Patrol agents.{{Cite news|last1=Carranza |first1=Rafael |url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/border-issues/2018/05/11/border-patrol-agent-lonnie-swartz-retried-death-jose-antonio-elena-rodriguez/602687002/|title=Border Patrol agent will be retried in fatal cross-border shooting of teen|date=11 May 2018|work=[[The Arizona Republic]]|access-date=20 June 2018|language=en}} ==Similar incidents== A 2015 review by the Border Patrol's [[Internal affairs (law enforcement)|internal affairs]] department reviewed 67 shooting incidents that resulted in 19 people dying, during the period from January 2010 through October 2012. The review found agents guilty of criminal conduct in 3 of the incidents. Two agents faced disciplinary action in the form of an "oral reprimand." ==See also== *[[List of killings by law enforcement officers in the United States, October 2012]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{cite journal |last=The Police Executive Research Forum |first=|url=https://www.cbp.gov/sites/default/files/documents/PERFReport.pdf|date=February 2013 |title=U.S. Customs and Border Protection Use of Force Review: Cases and Policies|journal= |volume=|pages=|bibcode= |doi=}} {{Mexican Drug War}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rodriguez, Killing of José}} [[Category:International incidents]] [[Category:People shot dead by law enforcement officers]] [[Category:Mexico–United States border]] [[Category:2012 in Arizona]] [[Category:2012 in Mexico]] [[Category:Mexican Drug War]] [[Category:October 2012 events in North America]] [[Category:Nogales, Arizona]] [[Category:Nogales, Sonora]]

{{Unreferenced|date=August 2017}} A '''latent human error''' is a [[human error]] which is likely to be made due to systems or routines that are formed in such a way that humans are disposed to making these errors. Latent human error is a term used in safety work and accident prevention, especially in [[aviation]].
By gathering data about errors made, then collating, grouping and analyzing them, it can be determined whether a disproportionate amount of similar errors are being made. If this is the case, a contributing factor may be disharmony between the respective systems/routines and human nature or [[Propensity probability|propensities]]. The routines or systems can then be analyzed, potential problems identified, and amendments made if necessary, in order to prevent future errors, incidents or accidents.
== See also == *[[Air safety]] *[[Error]]
==Further reading== * James Reason: ''Human Error'', Cambridge University Press; 1st edition (October 26, 1990) {{ISBN|978-0-521-31419-0}}
==External links== * Erik Hollnagel, [http://www.ida.liu.se/~eriho/HumanError_M.htm "The Elusiveness of "Human Error""], 2005 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20030712194750/http://bmj.com/cgi/reprint/320/7237/768.pdf ''Human error: models and management'' – James Reason] British Medical Journal 2000;'''320''':768–70 (Internet Archive) * [http://www.hse.gov.uk/humanfactors/topics/core2.pdf Human factors view of accident causation]

{{Infobox organization | image = Ni_faru_tion!.gif | image_size = 100 px | type = [[Non-governmental organization]] | status = | purpose = [[Environmentalism]] | headquarters = [[Tallinn]], [[Estonia]] | coords = | language = | leader_name = [[Rainer Nõlvak]] | key_people = | name = Let's do it! World | former name = Teeme Ära! (2007-2008)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.teeme2008.ee/ |title=Teeme ära 2008 |date= |accessdate=2011-12-09}}</ref> | map2 = | abbreviation = | location = | region_served = 113 countries | membership = | general = | num_volunteers = 14,000,000 in 2016<ref name="involved">{{cite web|url=https://csr.qlik.com/a/single/?appid=4fde03c4-c690-4157-a89a-e2a4ce2ca103&obj=ZJejPsx&lang=en-US&opt=currsel&select=clearall/|title=Single Object|website=csr.qlik.com}}</ref> | website = [http://www.letsdoitworld.org/ www.letsdoitworld.org/] }}
[[File:Lets Do It Mediterranean action in Cyprus.jpg|thumb|Let's Do It! Mediterranean 2014 action in Cyprus]] [[File:Let's Do It! Afghanistan.jpg|thumb|Let's Do It! Afghanistan 2015]] '''Let's Do It! World''' is a global civic movement that started from [[Estonia]], asking people worldwide to join a series of local, national and regional clean-up events. Among other projects, it is the founder of '''[[World Cleanup Day]]'''.
The Let's Do It! movement was first conceived in Estonia in year 2008, where a country clean-up action called '''[[Let's Do It 2008|Let's do it!]]''' (in [[Estonian language|Estonian]]: "Teeme Ära!") cleaned up 10,000 tons of illegal waste by more than 50,000 volunteers in one day. Following Estonia's lead many countries also started their own country clean-up events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinkitimes.fi/htimes/domestic-news/general/15176-finland-gets-spring-cleaning.html |title=Finland gets spring cleaning |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |url=http://blog.heifer.org/2011/07/ukrainian-participants-clean-up-their.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120715071118/http://blog.heifer.org/2011/07/ukrainian-participants-clean-up-their.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-15 |title=Ukrainian Participants Clean Up Their Village |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02 }}</ref> In 2011 a new initiative called Let's do it! World was started with the aim of promoting massive clean-ups from 24 March 2012 till 15 September 2012.<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/cyberguided-cleanup-hopes-to-sweep-globe-2281350.html |title=Cyber-guided clean-up hopes to sweep globe |date= 2011-05-09|accessdate=2012-01-02 |location=London |work=The Independent}}</ref> After a successful World Cleanup 2012 project the next bigger goal is to have [[World Cleanup Day]] in 2018.
Today, the movement has grown into a network of 113 countries. All together, 14 million participants have been engaged in movement's activities.<ref>Kalev Leetaru: [https://www.forbes.com/sites/kalevleetaru/2016/07/30/how-pokemon-and-location-based-augmented-reality-could-save-the-planet/#4f804c9766cc "How Pokémon And Location-Based Augmented Reality Could Save The Planet"] Forbes, 2016-07-30</ref>
Let's Do It! World is an accredited member of the [[United Nations Environment Programme|United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP)]].
Since 2017, the movement uses [[W sign]] aka Three Fingers Up as a symbol.
{{TOC limit|limit=3}}
==The origins of the massive cleanup movement== On the 3rd of May 2008 over 50,000 people came out of their homes to clean up Estonia, the rest followed the process via all the media channels. That's 4% out of a population of 1,3 million - which would equal 15,3 million in the USA or 57 million in India. The idea spread from Estonia to the whole Europe and beyond.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20100125-anti-garbage-campaigners-plan-mass-internet-led-clean |title=Anti-garbage campaigners plan mass Internet-led clean up |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100129054219/http://www.france24.com/en/20100125-anti-garbage-campaigners-plan-mass-internet-led-clean |archivedate=2010-01-29 |df= }}</ref> Next spring, in 2009, Latvia and Lithuania cleaned their countries with more than 250,000 people participating and have done it henceforth for three years, engaging more people each year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hCNrezFwQUYGj2rJNJJ75ENwcDgQ |title=AFP: Massive clean-up drive in Latvia, Lithuania |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02}}</ref> On 20 March 2010 Portugal cleaned their country with 200,000 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euronews.net/2010/03/20/massive-countryside-clean-up-in-portugal/ |title=Massive countryside clean-up in Portugal |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02}}</ref> [[Let's Clean Slovenia in One Day!|Slovenia followed shortly]], breaking all records with 270,000 people (which is 13% of the overall population of the country) taking part in the action.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/video/?/video/international/2010/05/03/wv.clean.up.slovenia.cnn |title=CNN: Big clean up in Slovenia |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02}}</ref> In the beginning of June the same year, Kyiv, the capital of Ukraine was cleaned.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> By the end of 2011 more than 2.5 million people have participated in Let’s Do It! cleanup actions in 16 countries – Estonia, India, Slovenia, Serbia, Finland, Romania, Latvia, Lithuania, Portugal, Bulgaria, Moldova, Ukraine, Cambodia, Russia, Hungary and Brazil.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.letsdoitworld.org/statistics |title=Let's Do It! World country statistics |date= |accessdate=2011-12-09}}</ref>
==World Cleanup 2012== In 2012, starting from 24 March until 25 September, a series of cleanups happened around the globe, on all continents, bringing together millions of volunteers in 96 countries.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> The action was initiated on 24 March 2012 by [[Let's Clean Slovenia|volunteers in Slovenia]] and [[Portugal]].
To bring together doers and initiators and share existing experience – Let's Do It! teams were organizing workshops and regional gatherings, introducing the World Cleanup 2012 around the world. Each group or organisation was leading the cleanup action in their country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.letsdoitworld.org/countries |title=Let's Do It! World countries |date= |accessdate=2011-12-09}}</ref>
<gallery> Cleanup in Armenia.jpg|[[Armenia]] Let's Do It! Bangladesh 2012.jpg|[[Bangladesh]] Slovenska vojska v okoljski akciji Očistimo Slovenijo 2012 (4).jpg|[[Slovenia]] </gallery> ==World Cleanup actions until 2018== After a successful World Cleanup 2012 project, the network set more ambitious goals. During the [https://web.archive.org/web/20140310071639/http://www.letsdoitworld.org/news/civic-leaders-40-countries-gather-kosovo-erase-massive-waste-problem Let's Do It! Clean World Conference held in Prishtina], Kosovo on the 6th-9th of February 2014, it was agreed, that the aim of the global movement is to clean up the whole World from illegally dumped solid waste and to then keep the planet clean. To reach the essential transformation in the global society, the leaders of country cleanups set the ambitious goal to involve 380 million people by 2018. According to Let's Do It! World, this is around 5% of the world’s population and is estimated to be the amount to create a lasting change.
==Biggest cleanup actions== [[File:Let's Do It! Ukraine 2015.jpg|thumb|Let's Do It! Ukraine 2015]] The most massive cleanup actions (data: October 2014) within the movement have happened in Slovenia, Bulgaria, Latvia, Lithuania, Kosovo and in Albania.
In 2012, 289,000 '''Slovenians''' came out of the homes and cleaned up the entire country in just one day. This is 14% of the country's population.
In 2013, 375,000 cleaned up the country in '''Bulgaria''' in a one-day country cleanup action (13,9% of country's population).
In 2012, 210,000 people (10% of country's population) cleaned up '''Latvia''' from illegal waste in just one day.
In 2013, a massive civic cleanup action also took place in '''Kosovo''', bringing together 132,000 people (7% of the population) and in the same year, Albania also had a massive cleanup action, uniting 147,000 people (5,25%) to clean up the country in just one day.
In 2015, 250,000 people (8,6% of country's population) cleaned up '''Lithuania''' from illegal waste in one day.
In 2015, over 500,000 people participated in Let's Do It! actions in '''Ukraine''' cleaning up illegal dump-sites around the country.
==World Cleanup 2018== {{Main|World Cleanup Day}}
Around 15 millions people in 158 countries took part on the World Clean Up Day, the 15th of September 2018.
== Prize == * 2017 : [[European Citizens' Prize]] * 2018 : [[The UNESCO-Japan Prize on Education for Sustainable Development]]
==See also== *[[Rainer Nõlvak]] *National CleanUp Day http://www.nationalcleanupday.org
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== {{Commonscat|Let's Do It! World}} *{{official website|http://www.letsdoitworld.org/}} *[https://www.youtube.com/user/Letsdoitworld Official Youtube Channel] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A5GryIDl0qY Video about Let's Do It! Estonia] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ACPehcr4Ydw Video about the global action - Let's Do It! World]

This is a '''list of [[Renaissance fair]]s''' worldwide. ==America== ===United States=== Included below are the fairs in the United States which are either notably long running or which regularly have had at least a two-week or better run. Generally, renaissance fairs are open weekends-only during the periods indicated. page.title: List of fan conventions by date of founding

revision.text:
The '''list of modern [[fan conventions]]''' for various genres of entertainment extends to the first conventions held in the 1930s.
Some fan historians claim that the 1936 Philadelphia Science Fiction Conference, a.k.a. [[Philcon]], was the first science fiction convention ever held. Others, such as [[Fred Patten]] and [[Rob Hansen]], make this claim for the January 1937 event in [[Leeds]], [[England]],<ref>Mike Glyer. [http://www.fiawol.org.uk/fanstuff/THEN%20Archive/1937conFirst.htm "THE FIRST EVER CONVENTION,"] ''The Story So Far'' (Worldcon, 1987).</ref> organized by the Leeds Science Fiction League, which was specifically organised as a conference, with a program and speakers. Out of this came the first incarnation of the [[British Science Fiction Association]].
While a few conventions were created in various parts of the world within the period between 1935-1960, the number of convention establishments increased slightly in the 1960s and then increased dramatically in the 1970s, with many of the largest conventions in the modern era being established during the latter decade. Impeti for further establishment of local fan conventions include:
* The return of superhero characters and franchises during the [[Silver Age of Comic Books]] (1956-1970) * science fiction adaptations for television serials (e.g., ''[[Star Trek]]'') in the 1960s-1970s * the growth of role-playing (in the 1970s and 1980s) as a genre of tabletop, live-action and eventually video/computer gaming, which not only inspired roleplay of favorite characters in full-body costumes but also inspired existing franchises to adapt their themes for said methods of gaming * the growth in home taping (starting with VHS in the late 1970s) of television broadcasts, including popular serials. * the growth of computerized communication, including the Internet and Internet-dependent applications in the 1980s and 1990s.
{{TOC right}}
