{{BLP sources|date=May 2011}} {{cleanup-PR|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox musical artist |name = Pete Lawrence |background = non_vocal_instrumentalist |image = Petelawrence.jpg |image_size = |caption = Pete Lawrence in 2008. |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|10|29|df=yes}} |origin = [[Leamington Spa]], England |death_date = |genre = [[Ambient music|Ambient]]
[[Electronica]]
[[Chillout]] |occupation = [[DJ]], [[Event planning|event organiser]], [[musician]], music programmer |years_active = 1986 – present |label = Big Chill Recordings
[[Cooking Vinyl]] |website = http://www.petelawrence.net/ |current_members = |past_members = }} '''Pete Lawrence''' is a conceptualist, social entrepreneur, recording artist, DJ, event organiser, music programmer writer and broadcaster based in the UK. ==Background== Lawrence created the concept for [[The Big Chill (music festival)|The Big Chill]] in February 1994, originally as a new type of Sunday multimedia club.{{Cite news|url=http://www.petelawrence.net/the_big_chill|title=The Big Chill|newspaper=Pete Lawrence|access-date=2017-01-09}} With his partner at the time, Katrina Larkin, he put together an event at which people were able to network and enjoy an experimental, audio-visual environment, as part of a multi-faceted eight-hour event. It was the first London club to have its own website and to offer free internet access and was initially noted for its ambient and downtempo soundtrack, contributing to the development of the chill out’ boom at the turn of the Millennium. This “festival in a club” concept adapted relatively easily to an outdoors setting and in 1995 Pete Lawrence and Katrina Larkin staged the first Big Chill Festival, reaching a capacity of 35,000 by 2007 as one of the top UK festivals. He was also instrumental in taking The Big Chill concept to several locations worldwide in collaboration with The [[British Council]]. Lawrence was also involved in The Big Chill's expansion into opening London venues. The Big Chill Bar in Brick Lane, was followed in autumn 2006 with the three story Big Chill House in Kings Cross as well as releasing his own recording project [[Chilled By Nature]]. It included a number of EPs, one-off tracks and collaborations, live performances at The Big Chill festival, and the debut album ''Under One Sun''. In the mid 80s, he established the [[Cooking Vinyl]] label and recorded 'The Texas Campfire Tapes' with singer-songwriter Michelle Shocked which went to No 1 in the UK Independent album charts. He co-edited the book ''Crossfade - a Big Chill Anthology'' (Serpents Tail). In December 2007, Pete Lawrence and Katrina Larkin were voted into Time Out's Top 100 ‘movers and shakers’.{{Cite news|url=http://www.virtualfestivals.com/Pete-Lawrence|title=Pete Lawrence - Virtual Festivals|last=Jasinski|first=Mr|newspaper=Virtual Festivals|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-01-09}} Lawrence stood down as a director and shareholder of Chillfest (The Big Chill) in February 2008.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/money/2010/oct/09/pete-lawrence-big-chill|title=My greatest mistake: Pete Lawrence|last=Snowdon|first=Graham|date=2010-10-08|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2017-01-09}} In September 2017, Lawrence's new project [https://campfireconvention.uk Campfire Convention] launched as a social network and membership based events community. Campfire's aims include : Building a social movement around values, bringing people together to find common ground, real life meet ups, connections and conversations : campaigning, initiatives and engagement at local level via Campfire Beacons, building resources for reference and activism, pioneering a new journalistic media voice, creating new models for a post-capitalist world which reward engagement and global cultural exchange. Campfire's first outdoor Convention was in August 2016 in Michaelchurch Escley, Herefordshire which included keynote addresses from their patron Brian Eno and peace activist Scilla Elworthy as well as panels, thinkshops, music, art and yoga. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.petelawrence.net/ Pete Lawrence] * [http://www.chilledbynature.net/ Chilled By Nature] * [http://www.bigchill.net/ The Big Chill] * [https://campfireconvention.uk/ Campfire Convention] {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lawrence, Pete}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British DJs]] [[Category:Chill-out musicians]] [[Category:People from Royal Leamington Spa]] [[Category:British company founders]] [[Category:Event planners]]

revision.comment: Remove 1 stray access-date. ([[User:GreenC bot/Job 5|GreenC bot job #5]])
revision.text:
[[File:Solomon Curve.png|thumb|right|The Solomon curve as published in [http://openlibrary.org/books/OL5932445M/Accidents_on_main_rural_highways_related_to_speed_driver_and_vehicle "Accidents on main rural highways related to speed, driver, and vehicle"]]]
The '''Solomon curve''' is a [[graphical representation]] of the collision rate of automobiles as a function of their speed compared to the average vehicle speed on the same road. The curve was based on [[research]] conducted by David Solomon in the late 1950s and published in 1964.<ref>{{cite news | first=David | last=Solomon | title=Accidents on main rural highways related to speed, driver, and vehicle | date=July 1964, Reprinted 1974 | publisher=Technical report, U.S. Department of Commerce/Bureau of Public Roads (precursor to Federal Highway Administration)| work = | pages = }}</ref> Subsequent research suggests significant biases in the Solomon study, which may cast doubt on its findings.<ref>{{cite news | title=Travelling Speed and the Risk of Crash Involvement on Rural Roads | date=July 2001 | publisher=Road Accident Research Unit, Adelaide University | url=http://casr.adelaide.edu.au/ruralspeed/RURALSPEED.PDF}}</ref>
== The original research == In 1964, Solomon researched the relationship between [[average]] [[speed]] and the [[collision]] [[Rate (mathematics)|rates]] of [[automobile]]s and plotted the results.<ref>{{cite book | last = Meyer | first = John Robert | authorlink = |author2=José A. Gómez-Ibáñez |author3=William B. Tye |author4=Clifford Winston | title = Essays in Transportation Economics and Policy | publisher = Brookings Institution Press | date = February 1999 | location = | pages = 275 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=MFhkehz-Ky0C&pg=PA257&dq=%22Solomon+curve%22 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-8157-3181-8 }}</ref> While others have attempted to quantify the relationship between average speed and collision rates, Solomon's work was both "the earliest and best known".<ref name="Travelling Speed and the Risk of Crash Involvement">{{cite web | url=http://casr.adelaide.edu.au/speed/vol-1.html | title=Travelling Speed and the Risk of Crash Involvement |pages=Section 2.1 | accessdate=3-1-2009 |vauthors=Kloeden CN, McLean AJ, Moore VM, Ponte G | date=November 1997| publisher= | quote=}}</ref> Solomon conducted a comprehensive study of more than 10,000 collision-involved drivers and their vehicles and how other roadway, driver, and vehicle characteristics affect the probability of being involved in a crash.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Cost-Benefit Evaluation of Large Truck- Automobile Speed Limit Differentials on Rural Interstate Highways|journal=University of Arkansas, Department of Industrial Engineering|date=November 2005|first=Steven L.|last=Johnson|author2=Naveen Pawar|volume=|issue=|pages=Page 24|id=|url=http://ww2.mackblackwell.org/web/research/ALL_RESEARCH_PROJECTS/2000s/2048/Final%20MBTC%20Report%202048%2011-8.doc|format=MS Word|accessdate=2009-03-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727051900/http://ww2.mackblackwell.org/web/research/ALL_RESEARCH_PROJECTS/2000s/2048/Final%20MBTC%20Report%202048%2011-8.doc|archivedate=2011-07-27|df=}}</ref> He found that the probability of being involved in a crash per vehicle-mile as a function of on-road vehicle speeds follows a U-shaped curve with speed values around the median speed having the lowest probability of being in a crash.<ref>{{Cite book| first=Kuei-Yuan | last=Chan|author2=Steven J. Skerlos |author3=Panos Y. Papalambros | contribution=A CASE STUDY IN VEHICLE EMISSIONS REGULATIONS TO ACHIEVE AMBIENT AIR QUALITY STANDARDS| title=Proceedings of IDETC/CIE 2006| editor-first=| editor-last=| publisher=ASME| place=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania| pages=8| date=2006-09-10| id= | contribution-url=http://ode.engin.umich.edu/publications/PapalambrosPapers/2006/231.pdf| format=PDF| accessdate=2009-03-01| editors= }}</ref> Although typically called the Solomon curve, the U-shaped curve has also been referred to as the Crash Risk Curve.<ref name="Is speed killing us?">{{cite web | url=http://www.sense.bc.ca/research.htm | title=Is speed killing us? | accessdate=3-1-2009 | author=Society for Safety by Education Not Speed Enforcement | quote=}}</ref>
== Subsequent research == In 1968, Julie Cirillo conducted a similar study of 2,000 vehicles on interstate highways that addressed speed variation’s impact on crashes that involved two or more vehicles.<ref>{{cite book | last = Cirillo |first=J. A.|title = Interstate System Accident Research Study II, Interim Report II, Public Roads, 35 (3) |year = 1968|pages = 71–75 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = }}</ref> The Cirillo data produced a U-shaped curve similar to the Solomon curve.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Cost-Benefit Evaluation of Large Truck- Automobile Speed Limit Differentials on Rural Interstate Highways|journal=University of Arkansas, Department of Industrial Engineering|date=November 2005|first=Steven L.|last=Johnson|author2=Naveen Pawar|volume=|issue=|pages=Page 25|id=|url=http://ww2.mackblackwell.org/web/research/ALL_RESEARCH_PROJECTS/2000s/2048/Final%20MBTC%20Report%202048%2011-8.doc|format=MS Word|accessdate=2009-03-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727051900/http://ww2.mackblackwell.org/web/research/ALL_RESEARCH_PROJECTS/2000s/2048/Final%20MBTC%20Report%202048%2011-8.doc|archivedate=2011-07-27|df=}}</ref> The [[Research Triangle Institute]] conducted a study in 1970 where data was collected on 114 crashes involving 216 vehicles on a state highway in Indiana to address these concerns by (1) combining automated, embedded speed-monitoring stations with trained on-scene crash investigators, and (2) distinguishing data on vehicles slowing to negotiate a turn from vehicles moving slowly in the flow of traffic.<ref>Research Triangle Institute, "Speed and Accident, Volume II," Report No. FH-11-6965, National Highway Safety Bureau, June 1970.</ref> Reporting on these results in 1971, academics West and Dunn confirmed the findings of Solomon and Cirillo,<ref name="Impacts and Issues Related to Proposed Changes in Oregon’s Interstate Speed Limits">{{cite web | url=http://www.its.pdx.edu/speedlimits/final%20interstate%20speed%20review%20report%20(9.12).pdf | title=Impacts and Issues Related to Proposed Changes in Oregon’s Interstate Speed Limits | accessdate=3-1-2009 | author=Monsere, C. M., Newgard, C., Dill, J. Rufolo, A., Wemple, E., Bertini, R. L., and Milliken, C. | date=September 2004 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6H4UFKRFH?url=http://www.its.pdx.edu/speedlimits/final%20interstate%20speed%20review%20report%20%289.12%29.pdf | archivedate=2013-06-02 | df= }}</ref> but found that crashes involving turning vehicles accounted for 44 percent of all crashes observed in the study and that excluding these crashes from the analysis greatly attenuated the factors that created the U-shape of the Solomon curve.<ref>West, L. B., Jr. and Dunn, J. W. (1971). "Accidents, Speed Deviation and Speed Limits." Traffic Engineering. 41 (10), 52-55</ref>
In 1991, Fildes, Rumbold, and Leening collected self-reported crash data from 707 motorists in Australia with fewer than 200 reporting that they had been in a collision but, unlike Solomon and Cirillo, the researchers found no relationship between slower speeds and increased crash involvement.<ref name="Speed Behaviour and Drivers’ Attitude to Speeding">{{cite web | url=http://www.monash.edu.au/muarc/reports/muarc016.html | title=Speed Behaviour and Drivers’ Attitude to Speeding | accessdate=3-2-2009 |vauthors=Fildes BN, Rumbold G, Leening A | date=June 1991 | location = Monash University Accident Research Centre, Victoria Australia, | quote=}}</ref> Notwithstanding the many studies over the years, in testimony before the Ohio Senate Highways and Transportation Committee on June 10, 2003, Julie Cirillo, Former Assistant Administrator and Chief Safety Officer for the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration ([[FMCSA]]), testified that "up to the present time there has been no evidence to alter Solomon’s original finding that variance from the mean operating speed is a major contributor to accidents".<ref name="Testimonyof2003">{{cite news|title=Testimony of Julie Anna Cirillo |date=2003-06-10 |publisher=OOIDA |url=http://www.landlinemag.com/Special_Reports/2003/June03/Cirillo_Testimony.htm |work=Land Line Magazine |pages= |accessdate=2009-03-02 |language= |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040816035301/http://www.landlinemag.com/Special_Reports/2003/June03/Cirillo_Testimony.htm |archivedate=August 16, 2004 }}</ref>
In July 2001, Kloeden CN, Ponte G and McLean AJ of the Road Accident Research Unit, Adelaide University quantified the relationship, "... between free travelling speed and the risk of involvement in a casualty crash in 80 km/h or greater speed limit zones in rural South Australia" using a case control study design. They found, "..the risk of involvement in a casualty crash increased more than exponentially with increasing free travelling speed above the mean traffic speed and that travelling speeds below the mean traffic speed were associated with a lower risk of being involved in a casualty crash." Outlining past research in this area, they suggest that, in the Solomon research, "Both the numerator (number of crashes in a particular speed band) and the denominator (number of vehicle-miles travelled in that same speed band) may have been quite inaccurate for relatively low speeds." <ref>{{cite news | title=Travelling Speed and the Risk of Crash Involvement on Rural Roads | date=July 2001 | publisher=Road Accident Research Unit, Adelaide University | url=http://casr.adelaide.edu.au/ruralspeed/RURALSPEED.PDF}}</ref>
== Theoretical foundation == Hauer provided a theoretical foundation for the Solomon curve in 1971—“for example, if I drive at 45 mph, while the [[median]] of the pack is 60 mph, how many cars will pass me in an hour and hence have a chance to collide with me?”—that showed that the theoretical [[Frequency distribution|distribution]] was nearly identical to the Solomon curve.<ref name="Essays in Transportation Economics and Policy">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MFhkehz-Ky0C&pg=PA276&lpg=PA276&dq=%22The+Solomon+Curve%22 | title=Essays in Transportation Economics and Policy | accessdate=3-1-2009 |author1=John Robert Meyer |author2=José A. Gómez-Ibáñez |author3=William B. Tye |author4=Clifford Winston | pages=Page 276 | isbn=978-0-8157-3181-8 | date=1999-02}}</ref>
== Practical implications == While Solomon’s research focused on speed deviation, and not speed per se, some commentators have cited Solomon’s research to support the conclusion that raw speed and crash risk are not directly related.<ref name="Is speed killing us?"/> On the other hand, while recognizing Solomon's research reveals the importance to safety of variability around average speed, Leonard Evans concludes in ''[[Traffic Safety and the Driver]]'' that control of absolute driver speed, and not variability, should be the primary focus of traffic safety regulation.<ref>{{cite book | last = Evans | first = Leonard| title = Traffic Safety and the Driver | publisher = Van Nostrand Reinhold | year = 1991 | location = New York, New York | pages = 155–56 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=OyuGJJ6rKQ0C&pg=PA155&lpg=PA155&dq=%22Traffic+Safety+and+the+Driver%22+Solomon| isbn = 0-442-00163-0 }}</ref> Both views support the fact that the seminal research underlying the Solomon curve shows that the greater the difference between a driver’s speed and the average speed of traffic—both above and below that average speed—the greater the likelihood of involvement in a crash.<ref>{{cite book | last = Transportation Research Board | first = Committee for Guidance on Setting and Enforcing Speed Limits | title = Managing Speed | publisher = National Research Council (U.S.) | year = 1998 | location = | pages = 46 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=pARs53U6NAQC&pg=PA224&dq=%22drive+with+the+flow+of+traffic”+Solomon | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-309-06502-X }}</ref> Consequently, many states and safety organizations advise drivers to “drive with the flow of traffic”.<ref name="Testimonyof2003" />
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Assured Clear Distance Ahead]] * [[Automobile safety]] * [[Car accident]] * [[Design speed]] * [[Operating speed]] * [[Road-traffic safety]] * [[Speed limit]] * [[Traffic engineering (transportation)]] * [[Traffic psychology]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Accidents]] [[Category:Car safety]] [[Category:Causes of death]] [[Category:Traffic collisions]] [[Category:Road safety]]

revision.comment: Removed [[:Template:New unreviewed article]] because it is going to be deleted
revision.text:
{{Infobox podcast | title = The Fifth Column Podcast | image = The_Fifth_Column_Podcast_Logo.jpg | host = Kmele Foster, Matt Welch, Michael C. Moynihan | genre = News & Politics | format = MP3 | updates = Weekly | length = 50-120 mins | language = English | began = Apr 1, 2016 | website = {{URL|http://wethefifth.com}} }}
'''The Fifth Column Podcast''' is an American politics, news and humor podcast founded in April, 2016. The show is hosted by [[Kmele Foster]], with co-hosts [[Michael C. Moynihan]], [[Matt Welch]] and produced by contributor [https://www.anthonylfisher.com/ Anthony L. Fisher] and Daniel Bier. The podcast is described as in each episode as an “...almost weekly thoughtful commentary on the news, those who make it and occasionally ourselves”<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wethefifth.com/episodes/2018/3/12/stormy-social-media-q-mdf8t-gwmfc-mlw4s-dlwdt-xxtzd-psbc3-xmyrf-6ml8a-bgcn4-ns82z-ny8yb-ww44l-sr9ce-2zhfh-3zbfs-ez68r-zsjyw-ymsts-glnfc-p77pw-mwa47-hb2fy-85b74|title=116 w/ Harry Siegel "Soros' Paid Protest Mobs, Team Woke vs Team Resentment"|last=|first=|date=|website=wethefifth.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. The show is closely associated with independent-leaning, libertarian and anarcho-capitalist ideology as presented by the show hosts and guests, but is not explicitly so.
=== Background and Format === '''[http://wethefifth.com/ The Fifth Column Podcast]''' first aired on iTunes April 2, 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/the-fifth-column-analysis-commentary-sedition/id1097696129?mt=2|title=The Fifth Column Podcast - iTunes|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The show markets itself as “Analysis. Commentary. Sedition” on Instagram<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/we.the.fifth/|title=The Fifth Column Podcast - Instagram|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and as “@MattWelch @mcmoynihan @Kmele pick apart the news, interrogate their guests and question just about everything #someidiotwrotethis” on Twitter<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/wethefifth|title=wethefifth - Twitter|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. The introduction to the podcast typically describes itself as: “…your almost weekly rhetorical assault on the news cycle, the people who make it and occasionally ourselves…”. Credit for the shows creation has been attributed to the encouragement of [[Kennedy (commentator)|Kennedy]] (Lisa Kennedy Montgomery) and her husband Dave Lee, who are associates of the hosts. The name of the podcast has been attributed to a suggestion by [[Katherine Mangu-Ward]] as revealed in Episode 13 (3:05 mark)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/the-fifth-column-analysis-commentary-sedition/id1097696129?mt=2|title="Islamic [REDACTED] and OJ Simpson"|last=|first=|date=June 21, 2016|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. The original music that opens and closes the podcast includes a soundbite of F.D.R.’s speech given 1940/05/27 warning prejudices exploited by Fifth [[iarchive:1940-05-27_FDR_Warns_of_Fifth_Column|Columnists]]. (https:archive.org)
=== Reception === ''Reason.com'' regularly promotes The Fifth Column in its ''Hit & Run'' segments<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://reason.com/blog/2016/04/01/whose-foreign-policy-is-really-dumb-the|title=Whose Foreign Policy Is Really Dumb; the Elephant Man Theory of Beauty Pageants, and ‘Some Idiot Wrote This’—Introducing The Fifth Column Podcast|last=Welch|first=Matt|date=April 1, 2016|website=www.reason.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. Other promotions come by way of wearelibertarians.com<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wearelibertarians.com/libertarian-podcasts/|title=My Top 10 Libertarian Podcasts|last=Spangle|first=Chris|date=July 4, 2016|website=wearelibertarians.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>, rampantdiscourse.com<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rampantdiscourse.com/things-i-like-podcasts/|title=Things I Like: Podcasts|last=Essen|first=Paul|date=November 23, 2016|website=rampantdiscourse.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>, postlibertarian.com<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://postlibertarian.com/tag/the-fifth-column/|title=Trump Junior and Russia|last=|first=|date=July 15, 2017|website=postlibertarian.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and freedombunker.com<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://freedombunker.com/2017/05/19/should-we-even-care-about-trump-scandals-and-russia-michael-moynihan-and-thad-russell-duke-it-out-on-the-fifth-column/|title=Should we even care about Trump scandals and Russia? Michael Moynihan and Thad Russell duke it on on The Fifth Column|last=|first=|date=May 19, 2017|website=freedombunker.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>.
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == <!-- https://rampantdiscourse.com/things-i-like-podcasts/ https://postlibertarian.com/tag/the-fifth-column/ https://wearelibertarians.com/libertarian-podcasts/ https://www.anthonylfisher.com/ https://www.facebook.com/TheFifthColumnPodcast fifthcolumn.podbean.com twitter.com/wethefifth itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/the-fifth-column http://www.easycounter.com/report/wethefifth.com http://www.instagram.com/p/BgY35jYn_Y- https://twitter.com/wethefifth https://www.instagram.com/we.the.fifth/ https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/the-fifth-column-analysis-commentary-sedition/id1097696129?mt=2 -->
<!--- Categories - Libertarian, Podcasts, Podcast, Political Commentary--> [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:News]] [[Category:Political commentators]] [[Category:Media companies]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox concert | concert_name = This Is It | image = This Is It Michael Jackson banner.png | image_size = 220px | caption = | artist = [[Michael Jackson]] | type = | venue = | tour = | album = ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)|This Is It]]'' | start_date = July 13, 2009 | end_date = March 6, 2010 | number_of_legs = 2 | number_of_shows = 50 (cancelled) | duration = | support_act = | attendance = | gross = | website = {{URL|www.michaeljacksonlive.com|Official website}} | last_concert = [[Michael Jackson: Live at the Apollo 2002]]
(2002) | this_concert = '''This Is It'''
(2009–10) | Misc = }} '''This Is It''' was a planned [[concert residency]] by [[Michael Jackson]] which was scheduled to begin in July 2009 and end September 29, 2009 with a second leg which was scheduled to run from January 2010 through March 2010 with a total of 50 shows.https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/michael-jacksons-this-is-it-tour-balloons-to-50-show-run-stretching-into-2010-20090312 Jackson announced This Is It at a press conference in the [[The O2 Arena|O2 Arena]], stating that it would be his final series of concerts in London. [[AEG Live]], the concert promoters, released a promotional video that took up an entire commercial break, setting a record for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]. Initially, only 10 concerts were announced, but following public demand, 40 more concerts were added. Ticket sales broke several records and Jackson's album sales increased following the announcement; AEG Live estimated that the first 10 dates alone would have earned Jackson approximately £50 million. In preparation for the concert series, Jackson had been collaborating with high-profile figures including fashion designer [[Christian Audigier]], choreographer [[Kenny Ortega]] and bodybuilder [[Lou Ferrigno]]. Prior to Jackson's death in 2009, Allgood Entertainment sued Jackson for $40 million, claiming that he had breached an exclusivity agreement with them by agreeing to the This Is It concerts; the case was dismissed. After Jackson's death, AEG Live offered either refunds to ticket holders or a special "souvenir" ticket designed by Jackson. The cancelled shows, record-breaking ticket sales{{cite web |first=Daniel|last=Kreps |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2009/03/12/michael-jacksons-this-is-it-tour-balloons-to-50-show-run-stretching-into-2010/ |title=Michael Jackson’s "This Is It!" Tour Balloons to 50-Show Run Stretching Into 2010 |publisher=''Rolling Stone'' |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=March 24, 2009 }}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7941221.stm |agency=BBC News |title= Michael Jackson announces comeback gigs |publisher= ''[[BBC]]''|date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate= November 5, 2009 |last=BBC staff }}{{cite web |url= http://www.livedaily.com/news/18434.html |author= The Livedaily Staff |work= [[LiveDaily]] |title= Michael Jackson breaking records with 50-show run in London |date= March 9, 2009 |accessdate= November 5, 2009 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100209062136/http://livedaily.com/news/18434.html |archivedate= February 9, 2010 |df= mdy-all }} and potential for a world tour{{cite web |url= http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/entertainment/6405947/australia-part-of-planned-jackson-tour/ |title= Australia part of planned world tour |publisher=[[Yahoo! 7]] |date= October 30, 2009 |accessdate= November 5, 2009 |last=Australia |first=Yahoo }}{{cite web |url= http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1624853/20091027/story.jhtml?rsspartner=rssColdFusion |author= The MTV Staff |work= MTV |title= This Is It Director Kenny Ortega On Michael Jackson's Final Rehearsals |date= November 5, 2009 |accessdate= September 23, 2009}} led to This Is It being termed "the greatest concert[s] that never happened."{{cite web |first=IGN |last=Staff |url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/101/1016381p1.html|title=Michael Jackson’s "This Is It!" Tour Balloons to 50-Show Run Stretching Into 2010 |publisher=''IGN'' |date=August 20, 2009 |accessdate=November 5, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.michaeljackson.com/ru/this-is-it|title=''Jackson's This Is It This Fall'' | publisher=[[Sony]] |date=August 20, 2009 |accessdate=November 5, 2009|first=Sony |last=Staff}} [[Columbia Pictures]] acquired the footage of the rehearsals and released a [[concert film]], ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It]],'' accompanied by a [[Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)|compilation album of the same name]]. ==Promotion and significance== {{Wikinews|Michael Jackson to make last public concerts}} Jackson announced the first 10 performances during a press conference at the O2 Arena on March 5, 2009. As many as 7,000 fans and 350 reporters awaited Jackon's arrival, many donning Jackson-related clothing.{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/artists/michael-jackson/news/100481-jackson-set-to-announce-shows|title=Jackson set to announce shows|publisher=MTV|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} {{cite news |last= Akbar |first=Arifa |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/jacko-on-tour-this-will-be-the-final-curtain-call-i-love-you-i-love-you-all-1638497.html|title=Jacko on tour: 'This will be the final curtain call. I love you, I love you all' – News, Music |publisher=''[[The Independent]]''|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009 | location=London}} He commented at the conference, "I just wanted to say that these will be my final show performances in London. When I say this is it, it really means this is it", adding that it was his "final curtain call", although he may have just been referring to performing in London. Organizers touted the residency as, "dramatic shows [that] promise an explosive return with a band of the highest calibre, a state-of-the-art stage show and incredible surprise [[support act]]s".{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/4944927/Michael-Jackson-announces-comeback-gigs.html |title=Michael Jackson announces comeback gigs |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009 |last= Khan|first=Urmee | location=London}} Hours before the press conference, promotional posters for the residency were displayed around London. Further promotion took up an entire [[commercial break]] period on [[ITV London]] during ''[[Dancing on Ice (Series 4)|Dancing on Ice]]'', the first time this has ever happened for a musical artist. The advert, which cost £1 million to air, was viewed by 11 million people. {{cite web |last=Griffin|first=Zoe |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/03/04/michael-jackson-has-50-medical-tests-to-prove-he-can-manage-02-arena-dates-115875-21171604/|title=Michael Jackson has 50 medical tests to prove he can manage 02 Arena dates |publisher=''[[Daily Mirror]]''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} {{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7925388.stm|title= 'Final curtain call' for Jackson|publisher=BBC|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009|last=Youngs |first=Ian }} {{cite web|url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/News/MostEmailed/888126/Michael-Jackson-takes-entire-three-half-minute-ITV-ad-slot/ |title=Michael Jackson takes entire three and a half minute ITV ad slot |publisher=www.mediaweek.co.uk|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009|last=Barnett|first=Emma }}{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/03/09/michael-jackson-live-dates-ad-during-dancing-on-ice-seen-by-11m-fans-115875-21184002/|title=Michael Jackson live dates ad during Dancing On Ice seen by 11m fans|publisher=''Daily Mirror''|date=March 9, 2009|accessdate=March 9, 2009}} The shows, Jackson's first significant concert events since the [[Michael Jackson: 30th Anniversary Celebration]] in 2001, had been cited as one of the year's most important musical events,{{cite news|first=Rosie|last=Swash|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2009/mar/05/michael-jackson-o2-arena|title=Michael Jackson can't fail to sell out the O2 arena|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009 | location=London}} and as the greatest comeback in the history of pop.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1151504/Michael-Jackson-chooses-Londons-O2-arena-greatest-comeback-history.html|author=Simon Cable |work=[[Dailymail.co.uk]] |title=Michael Jackson chooses London's O2 arena for the 'greatest comeback in history'|date=November 5, 2009 |accessdate=February 21, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/43249|title=Michael Jackson announces O2 Arena London gigs — and retirement?|publisher=''[[NME]]''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} Randy Phillips, president and chief executive of [[AEG Live]], stated that the first 10 dates would earn Jackson approximately £50 million (about US$80.1 million).{{cite news|first=Patrick |last= Foster |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article5854735.ece|title=Michael Jackson grand finale curtain-raiser|publisher=''[[The Times]]''|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009 | location=London}} ''[[The Guardian]]'' characterized the concerts as an "astonishing comeback for a man who in recent years has been dogged by controversy", adding that Jackson still had "enormous commercial clout". The ''[[Evening Standard]]'' stated that the deal was the "showbiz coup of the decade" for AEG Live, while ''[[The Independent]]'' remarked that the finalized 50 concerts would provide London with a "much-needed" economic boost.{{cite web |first=Amar |last=Singh |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23661911-details/Detoxing+brand+Jacko/article.do |title=Detoxing Brand Jacko |publisher=''[[Evening Standard]]'' |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=March 24, 2009 }}{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/the-barometer-michael-jackson-angela-gheorghiu-horne-and-corden-madonna-in-fancy-dress-1649091.html |title=The Barometer: Michael Jackson; Angela Gheorghiu; Horne and Corden; Madonna in fancy dress |publisher=''The Independent'' |date=March 20, 2009 |accessdate=March 25, 2009 | location=London}} Joe Cohen, chief executive of [[Seatwave]], told [[BBC 6 Music]] that the shows would generate £1 billion for the economy.{{cite web |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/metrolife/music/article.html?Michael_Jackson_in_billion_pound_boost_to_economy&in_article_id=652877&in_page_id=25 |title=Michael Jackson in 'billion pound' boost to economy |publisher=''[[Metro (Associated Metro Limited)|Metro]]'' |date=May 8, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} ==Public interest== [[File:O2 with Canary Wharf and City of London (15007282651).jpg|right|thumb|250px|The O2 Arena, where the concerts would have been held]] Some websites offered early tickets, which the [[Association of Secondary Ticket Agents]] warned were fake. "We are warning people not to buy tickets that are not yet on sale because it is unlikely that they will receive those tickets", announced the organization's chief, Graham Burns. He concluded, "It's impossible when the dates haven't been announced to be selling tickets for something when there are no announced dates".{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/43235|title=Michael Jackson London 02 Arena ticket warning issued|publisher=''NME''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} Jackson's official website allowed fans to register early for a "pre-sale" draw. Some fans had difficulty applying, as the website could not deal with the large number of registrations—reportedly up to 16,000 applications a second.{{cite news |first=Matthew|last=Moore|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/4945911/Michael-Jackson-O2-ticket-website-attracting-16000-visits-a-second.html|title=Michael Jackson O2 ticket website attracting 16,000 visits a second |publisher=''The Daily Telegraph'' |date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009 | location=London}} In the space of 24 hours, nearly a million people from around the world registered for pre-sale tickets, enough to fill the venue 50 times over.{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/03/06/michael-jackson-adds-10-more-dates-to-comeback-tour-115875-21177334/|title=Michael Jackson adds 10 more dates to comeback tour |publisher=''Daily Mirror'' |date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/artists/michael-jackson/news/102275-michael-jackson-announces-dates |title=Michael Jackson Announces Dates |publisher=MTV |date=March 10, 2009 |accessdate=March 29, 2009 }} Tickets that had not even been printed were selling on auction website [[eBay]] for £300.{{cite news|first=Elizabeth |last=Day |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/mar/08/michael-jackson-profile-pop-culture |title=Off the wall but still invincible |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=March 8, 2009|accessdate=March 8, 2009 | location=London}} Sales of Jackson's albums increased following the press conference. Overnight, sales of ''[[Off the Wall]]'' rose 200%, ''[[Bad (album)|Bad]]'' rose 110%, ''[[Dangerous (Michael Jackson album)|Dangerous]]'' rose 165% and ''[[Thriller 25]]'' rose 155%.* {{cite web |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/music/article2302221.ece |title=Jacko's album sales are backo|date=March 7, 2009 |publisher=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310080317/http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/music/article2302221.ece |archive-date=March 10, 2009 |dead-url=yes}} The two-day pre-sale began on March 11, and 40 extra dates were added to meet high demand—five of these dates were reserved in their entirety for the public sale. More than 1.5  million fans caused two sites offering pre-sale tickets to crash within minutes of going online.{{cite web |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/showbiz/article-23660868-details/1.5m+fans+crash+sites+in+rush+for+Jacko+gig/article.do |title=1.5m fans crash sites in rush for Jacko gig |publisher=''Evening Standard'' |date=March 11, 2009 |accessdate=March 30, 2009 }} In the space of two hours, 190,000 tickets were sold.{{cite news |first=Simon |last=Cable |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1161160/Fans-fury-touts-sell-Michael-Jackson-concert-tickets-16-000-pair-black-market.html |title=Fans' fury as touts sell Michael Jackson concert tickets for up to £16,000 a pair on black market |publisher=''Daily Mail'' |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=March 30, 2009 | location=London}} Two million people tried to buy pre-sale tickets in the space of 18 hours.{{cite news |first=David |last=Miranda |url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,25175199-5006024,00.html |title=Michael Jackson doubles London shows after 2 million seek tickets |publisher=''[[Herald Sun]]'' |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} Veronica Schmidt of ''[[The Times]]'' stated of the reception, "Michael Jackson has floored his critics",{{cite news |first=Veronica |last=Schmidt |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/article5889522.ece |title=Michael Jackson sells out London concerts and adds more shows |publisher=''The Times'' |date=March 11, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} while organizers proclaimed it a "cultural phenomenon".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7940515.stm |title=Jackson to play 50 gigs at the O2 |publisher=BBC |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} It was announced that Jackson would break the record for number of shows performed by an artist at a single venue, which had been set by [[Prince (musician)|Prince]], who hosted a residency at the same arena for his [[21 Nights in London: The Earth Tour]] concerts. According to Jackson's website, the following records were or would have been broken: "The biggest audience ever to see an artist in one city", "The greatest number of people to attend a series of arena shows", "The fastest ticket sales in history". Randy Phillips acknowledged that Jackson could have sold out even more dates, but this would have conflicted with other career plans.{{cite web |first=Ray |last=Waddell |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/269213/update-michael-jackson-up-to-50-london-shows |title=Update: Michael Jackson Up To 50 London Shows |publisher=''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} On March 13, the other 50% of seats for dates 1–45 and all the seats for dates 46–50 went on sale to the general public. Within four hours, all 50 dates had sold out.* {{cite web |url=https://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jackson-This-Is-It-Shows-At-O2-Sell-Out-After-Tickets-Go-On-General-Sale/Article/200903215240762?lpos=Showbiz_News_First_Home_Article_Teaser_Region_1&lid=ARTICLE_15240762_Michael_Jackson_This_Is_It_Shows_At_O2_Sell_Out_After_Tickets_Go_On_General_Sale |title=Jackson's Tears Of Joy As O2 Shows Sell Out |date=March 13, 2009 |publisher=[[Sky News]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090316004206/https://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jackson-This-Is-It-Shows-At-O2-Sell-Out-After-Tickets-Go-On-General-Sale/Article/200903215240762?lpos=Showbiz_News_First_Home_Article_Teaser_Region_1&lid=ARTICLE_15240762_Michael_Jackson_This_Is_It_Shows_At_O2_Sell_Out_After_Tickets_Go_On_General_Sale |archive-date=March 16, 2009 |dead-url=yes}}} At this stage, the sales of ''[[King of Pop (album)|King of Pop]]'' were up 400% and the sales of ''[[Thriller (Michael Jackson album)|Thriller]]'' were up 200%.{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/Music/03/13/michael.jackson.concerts.tickets/ |title=750,000 tickets for Jackson concerts sell in 4 hours |publisher=CNN |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} Tickets appeared on eBay for as much as £10,000.{{cite news |first=Rosie |last=Swash |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/mar/13/michael-jackson-o2-arena-residency-sells-out |title=Michael Jackson's 50 dates at London's O2 arena sell out |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} ==Preparation and concert details== The 50-concert run was originally scheduled to start on July 8, 2009 and conclude on February 24, 2010.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8060282.stm |title=Jackson delays opening tour dates |publisher=BBC |date=May 20, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} Each of the shows would have been performed at the O2 Arena in London, which has a capacity of 23,000.{{cite web|first=Andre|last=Paine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/269278/michael-jackson-says-london-concerts-to-be-final-curtain-call|title=Michael Jackson Says London Concerts To Be 'Final Curtain Call'|publisher=''Billboard''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} New York-based fashion designer [[Zaldy]] served as head costumer, creating ten of Jackson's stage looks while the other six were created by his longtime costumers, Michael Bush and Dennis Tompkins. Jay Ruckel from La Crasia Gloves recreated Jackson's iconic single glove for the concerts.{{cite news |first=William |last=Sherman |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/money/2009/06/14/2009-06-14_theyre_still_proudly_making_it_in_nyc_manufacturing_alive__well_at_feisty_factor.html |title=Michael Jackson, Hubble Telescope draw from New York manufacturing |publisher=''[[New York Daily News]]'' |date=June 14, 2009|accessdate=June 20, 2009}} The costumes he was to wear during the shows were encrusted with 300,000 [[Swarovski crystals]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/45530|title=Extra Michael Jackson O2 Arena tickets made available|date=June 23, 2009|publisher=NME|accessdate=June 26, 2009}} In April 2009, thousands of dancers flew in from all around the world to audition from the 13th to the 15th for Jackson, who helped select the 11 finalists in person.{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/268649/michael-jackson-rehearsals-move-forward |title=Michael Jackson Rehearsals Move Forward |publisher=Billboard |date=May 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} [[Kenny Ortega]], who had collaborated with Jackson previously, was to work on the overall design and direction of concerts. Ortega said that the final product would have been a "theatrical musical experience".{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jackson-Auditions-Dancers-For-Tour-And-Works-With-Director/Article/200905215280285 |title=Michael Jackson Gets Ready For Tour |publisher=Sky News |date=May 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/44599 |title=Michael Jackson enlists 'High School Musical' director for London O2 shows |publisher=''NME'' |date=May 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }}{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jacksons-Comeback-Tour-12-Dancers-Picked-To-Join-Singer-On-Stage-At-Londons-O2-Aena/Article/200905315284334 |title=This Is It: Jacko Picks Comeback Gig Dancers |publisher=Sky News |date=May 19, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} According to Randy Philips, £13 million was to be spent on producing the concerts, which would have included 18–22 songs and 22 different sets. There also would have been [[Aerial dance|aerial dancing]] similar to routines by [[Cirque du Soleil]]. Carla Ferrigno told [[Reuters]] that [[Lou Ferrigno|her husband Lou]] had been helping Jackson train in advance of the shows. Jackson and Ferrigno had previously worked together.{{cite news |first=Alex |last=Dobuzinskis |url=http://blogs.reuters.com/fanfare/2009/06/19/the-hulk-trains-michael-jackson-ahead-of-london-concerts/ |title=The Hulk trains Michael Jackson ahead of London concerts |publisher=Reuters |date=June 19, 2009 |accessdate=June 19, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090621224923/http://blogs.reuters.com/fanfare/2009/06/19/the-hulk-trains-michael-jackson-ahead-of-london-concerts/ |archivedate=June 21, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} On May 20, it was announced that the first concert would be pushed back five days to July 13 and three other July dates would be rescheduled for March 2010. AEG Live said that the delay was necessary because more time was needed for dress rehearsals. The revised schedule called for 27 shows between July 13 and September 29, 2009, followed by a three-month break, before resuming in the new year with 23 more shows between January 7 and March 6, 2010. Some fans petitioned for the reversal of AEG Live's decision.{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/44820 |title=Michael Jackson fans launch petition over O2 Arena postponement |publisher=''NME'' |date=May 21, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} In late June, several hundred seats for each of the dates were put on sale. These seats were held back until production logistics were worked out.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8115638.stm |title=More Jackson tickets up for sale |publisher=BBC |date=June 23, 2009 |accessdate=June 25, 2009 }} It was suggested that after the London concerts, Jackson might head to [[Australia]], [[Europe]], [[India]], [[China]], [[Hong Kong]] and [[Japan]] before moving on to North America. Randy Phillips, the CEO of [[AEG Live]], told The LA Times that Australia was part of Michael Jackson's international tour plans.{{cite web |url=http://www.take40.com/news/16590/michael-jackson-planning-australian-tour-before-his-death |title=Michael Jackson Planning Australian Tour Before His Death |publisher=Take 40 |date=June 28, 2009 |accessdate=May 6, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504000236/http://www.take40.com/news/16590/michael-jackson-planning-australian-tour-before-his-death |archivedate=May 4, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} According to Jermaine Jackson's 2011 book ''You Are Not Alone: Michael Through a Brother's Eyes'', after the London concerts were finished, Jackson was planning to extend his deal with AEG Live which included new music, a potential three-picture movie deal, a series of one-off concert dates starting in China, a halftime slot at one of the future [[Super Bowl]] games to surpass his own halftime show at the [[Super Bowl XXVII]] in January 1993 and two more tours (one of which was to be a final reunion with his brothers based on a promise made to their [[Katherine Jackson|mother]] to see her sons perform together one last time before she passed away). After the deal was completed, he planned to take time off from musical entertainment and move on to (possibly) directing his own film ideas, such as making a feature-length motion picture based on his 1982 song "Thriller" and [[Michael Jackson's Thriller (music video)|the music video of the same name]]. It was also later revealed that [http://www.damienshields.com/michael-jacksons-halloween-special-that-never-was/ a yearly Halloween television special] based on his horror-themed songs, such as "Thriller" and "Ghosts", was part of Jackson's deal with AEG Live. In [[Trial of Conrad Murray|Conrad Murray's manslaughter trial]], David Walgren stated another one of Jackson's future plans was to open a children's hospital. This was heard in an audio tape Conrad Murray played of Jackson under the influence of propofol on May 10, 2009. His voice is barely recognisable in the recording, but he can be clearly heard saying that he wanted to build the greatest children's hospital in the world and name it after himself: The ''Michael Jackson's Children's Hospital''. Walgren also stated that while the tour was happening, Jackson wanted to buy an estate with streams, horses and animals so his three children, Prince, Paris and Blanket could live normal lives as their father performed the concerts, as he was photographed looking for a house in the United Kingdom with his children. Walgren also said that the tour would begin that summer, and Jackson could take his children out of school and bring them with him so they could see him perform in London. ===Songs prepared=== As shown in ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It]]'', songs prepared for the concerts included "[[Wanna Be Startin' Somethin']]", "[[Jam (song)|Jam]]", "[[They Don't Care About Us]]", "[[Human Nature (Michael Jackson song)|Human Nature]]", "[[Smooth Criminal]]", "[[The Way You Make Me Feel]]", a medley of songs by [[The Jackson 5]] consisting of "[[I Want You Back]]", "[[The Love You Save]]", "[[I'll Be There (The Jackson 5 song)|I'll Be There]]" and "[[Shake Your Body (Down to the Ground)]]", "[[I Just Can't Stop Loving You]]", "[[Thriller (song)|Thriller]]", "[[Beat It]]", "[[Black or White]]", "[[Earth Song]]", "[[Billie Jean]]", and "[[Man in the Mirror]]". Later on, "[[Stranger in Moscow]]", "[[You Are Not Alone]]", "[[Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough]]", "[[Rock with You (Michael Jackson song)|Rock with You]]", "[[Dirty Diana]]" ,"[[You Rock My World]]", "[[Dangerous (Michael Jackson song)|Dangerous]]", "[[We Are the World]]", "[[Heal the World]]" and "[[Will You Be There]]" were also confirmed to have been planned for the shows. Due to the larger than usual roster of songs, as well as time constraints, Jackson would perform some songs with one verse less than he did in previous tours (such as "Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'", "Jam", "The Way You Make Me Feel" and "Black or White"). "[[Bad (Michael Jackson song)|Bad]]" was rumored to have been reserved for select concerts. On the final dates, Jackson wanted to perform a ballad called "River Ripple", written by him, with an African choir and his children. During the final concert before "Man in the Mirror", Michael was slated to premiere a song called "Best of Joy", written and recorded in 2009 prior to Jackson's death. As of 2018, the full version of "River Ripple" remains unreleased (although snippets of the song have leaked on YouTube), while "Best of Joy" was officially released in 2010 on Jackson's first posthumous album of unreleased songs, ''[[Michael (album)|Michael]]''. ==Dates== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! style="width:130px;"| Date ! style="width:130px;"| City ! style="width:160px;"| Country ! style="width:180px;"| Venue |- |- style="background:#ddd;" |colspan="4"|'''First Leg''' |- |July 13, 2009 |rowspan="27"|[[London]] |rowspan="27"|[[United Kingdom]] |rowspan="27"|[[The O2 Arena|The O2 Arena]] |- |July 16, 2009 |- |July 18, 2009 |- |July 22, 2009 |- |July 24, 2009 |- |July 26, 2009 |- |July 28, 2009 |- |July 30, 2009 |- |August 1, 2009 |- |August 3, 2009 |- |August 10, 2009 |- |August 12, 2009 |- |August 17, 2009 |- |August 19, 2009 |- |August 24, 2009 |- |August 26, 2009 |- |August 28, 2009 |- |August 30, 2009 |- |September 1, 2009 |- |September 3, 2009 |- |September 6, 2009 |- |September 8, 2009 |- |September 10, 2009 |- |September 21, 2009 |- |September 23, 2009 |- |September 27, 2009 |- |September 29, 2009 |- |- 8, 2010 |- |February 10, 2010 |- |February 12, 2010 |- |February 16, 2010 |- |February 18, 2010 |- |February 20, 2010 |- |February 22, 2010 |- |February 24, 2010 |- |March 1, 2010 |- |March 3, 2010 |- |March 6, 2010 |- |} ==Personnel== {{col-begin}} {{col-3}} ;Musicians *[[Michael Jackson]] – [[Lead vocalist|vocals]], [[Artistic director (music)|show direction]], [[choreographer]] *[[Orianthi|Orianthi Panagaris]] – [[guitar]] *[[Tommy Organ]] – guitar *Alex Al – [[Bass guitar|bass]] *[[Jonathan Moffett]] – [[Drum kit|drums]] *Michael Bearden – [[Keyboard instrument|keyboard]]s, [[musical director]] *[[Morris Pleasure]] – keyboards *Bashiri Johnson – [[Percussion instrument|percussion]] *Dorian Holley – [[Backing vocalist|vocals]], vocal direction *[[Judith Hill]] – vocals *Darryl Phinnessee – vocals *Ken Stacey – vocals {{col-3}} ;Dancers *Michael Jackson *Daniel Yao{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wwkPZf4zRmk|title=This Is It dancers on the Ellen Show|year=2009|publisher=YouTube}} *Nicholas Basir *[[Daniel Celebre]] (a.k.a. Da FunkyMystic) *[[Mekia Cox]] *Chris Grant (a.k.a. Kriyss Grant) *[[Misha Gabriel]] *Shannon Holtzapffel *Devin Jamieson *[[Charles Klapow]] *[[Dres Reid|Ricardo Reid]] (aka Dres Reid) *Danielle Rueda Watts *Tyne Stecklein *Timor Steffens (a.k.a. Timor Dance) {{col-3}} ;Production and other personnel *[[Kenny Ortega]] – show direction *Alif Sankey – [[Assistant producer|associate production]] *Michael Cotten – [[Production designer|production design]] *Michael Curry – production design *Michael Jackson & [[Travis Payne]] – [[choreography]] *Stacy Walker – choreography assistance *Tony Testa – choreography assistance *Patrick Woodroffe – [[Lighting designer|lighting design]] *[[David Elsewhere]] – dance coaching *Shahzad Perez - Specialty Act *Gregg Smith – [[Casting (performing arts)|casting direction]] *Karen Faye Heinze – hair and make-up *[[Zaldy Goco]] – [[Costume designer|chief of costume design]] *Michael Bush – [[Costume designer|costume design]] *Dennis Thompkins - [[Costume designer|costume design]] *[[AEG Live]] – [[Promoter (entertainment)|promotion]] *Dave Polich - synth programming {{col-end}} ==Litigation== In June 2009, concert promoter Allgood Entertainment, represented by Ira Meyerowitz and Jon Kekielek of MJlawfirm, sued Jackson for $40 million. He claimed that Jackson, through his manager [[Frank DiLeo]], had agreed to a single and a $30 million reunion concert with [[The Jackson 5]] and his sister [[Janet Jackson]]. According to the concert promoter, the alleged contractual agreement prevented Jackson from performing elsewhere before the reunion concert and for a three-month period after it. Thus, agreeing to a 50 date residency at the O2 arena was an alleged breach of the Allgood Entertainment contract. The filing company stated that AEG Live knew of the alleged agreement with Jackson and used their dominance in the industry to coerce Jackson into agreeing to the residency.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8094537.stm |title=Jackson sued over reunion concert |publisher=BBC |date=June 11, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }}{{cite news |first=Sean |last=Michaels |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/jun/12/michael-jackson-sued-o2-arena|title=Michael Jackson sued for O2 arena residency|publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=June 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 | location=London}}{{cite news |first=Sean |last=Michaels |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/may/12/michael-jackson-comeback-concerts |title=Michael Jackson comeback concerts in jeopardy? |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=June 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 | location=London}} In August 2010, the judge dismissed the case, stating that there was no evidence of a binding agreement, no contracts were signed.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11038050 | work=BBC News | title=Judge dismisses Jackson reunion claim | date=August 20, 2010}} The case was in limbo as of 2013.{{cite web|url=http://archive.recapthelaw.org/nysd/347380/ |title=AllGood Entertainment, Inc. et al v. Jackson et al (nysd/347380) – The RECAP Archive |publisher=Archive.recapthelaw.org |date= |accessdate=May 6, 2013}}{{cite web|author=Yazmeen |url=http://muzikfactorytwo.blogspot.com/2011/05/interview-with-patrick-allocco.html |title=Interview with Patrick Allocco- President of AllGood Entertainment ~ LET'S CALL SPADE A SPADE |publisher=Muzikfactorytwo.blogspot.com |date=May 24, 2011 |accessdate=May 6, 2013}} ==Jackson's death and refunds== {{Further|Death of Michael Jackson}} On June 25, 2009, Jackson died after going into [[cardiac arrest]] which was caused by an overdose of [[Propofol]] and [[Benzodiazepine|benzodiazepines]], eighteen days before his planned first show. AEG Live, who persuaded Jackson to sign up for the shows, faced a liability of up to £300 million and an empty venue for the next nine months.{{cite news|last=Sherwin|first=Adam|title=O2 arena counts cost as curtain closes on the greatest show of all|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article6580748.ece|publisher=The Times|date=June 26, 2009|accessdate=June 26, 2009 | location=London}} The O2 arena stated that full refunds, including all ticket service charges, would be available to those who purchased tickets through authorized agents, but that "fans will have the option to be sent the actual tickets they would have received to attend the shows in lieu of the full refunds which are being offered."{{cite web |title=UCLA Statement — Michael Jackson|url=http://www.theo2.co.uk/inside/ucla-statement-michael-jackson.html |publisher=[[The O2 Arena]] |accessdate=July 1, 2009}} Fans who bought their tickets from private sellers potentially faced difficulties. eBay recommended that purchasers contact their sellers for refunds and stated that those who used PayPal can get their money back if the purchase was made during the last 45 days,{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8120412.stm |title=Refund issues over Jackson gigs |publisher=''BBC News'' |date=June 26, 2009 |accessdate=June 26, 2009}} then later stated that "all buyers on the site will receive a full refund for their ticket purchase".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8122580.stm |title=eBay will refund Jackson tickets |publisher=BBC News |date=June 27, 2009 |accessdate=June 27, 2009}} ==Posthumous film and album== {{Further|Michael Jackson's This Is It|Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)}} Following Jackson's death, AEG stated that they had over "100 hours of footage of preparations and rehearsals for the shows".{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/32360110 |title=Judge OKs Jackson performance film deal |agency=Associated Press |work=[[MSNBC|MSNBC.com]] |date=August 10, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009}} On August 10, 2009, Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Mitchell Beckloff approved a deal between film distributor [[Columbia Pictures]] and AEG Live for the former company to purchase and distribute rehearsal footage of Jackson for a film entitled ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/showbiz/2009-08/06/content_8532737.htm |title=Michael Jackson film deal outlined in court papers |work=ChinaDaily.com |date=August 6, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009}}{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-ct-jackson11-2009aug11,0,2938755.story |author=Christopher Smith |work=[[LA Times|LA Times.com]] |title=Sony Pictures to produce Michael Jackson film |accessdate=September 21, 2009 | date=August 11, 2009}} According to court documents, Columbia paid $60 million (£35 million) for rights to the rehearsal footage.{{cite web |url=http://www.uncut.co.uk/news/michael_jackson/news/13441 |title=Michael jackson This Is It film deal agreed |work=Uncut.co.uk |date=August 8, 2009|accessdate=October 3, 2009}} The papers filed in court had reportedly stated that Jackson's estate will get 90% of the profits and that AEG Live will get the remaining 10% from the film's revenue.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/aug/11/michael-jackson-film-october-release |author=Rosie Swash |title=Michael Jackson film gets October release date |work=[[Guardian.co.uk]] |date=August 11, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009 | location=London}} The film was directed by [[Kenny Ortega]] who was also the director of the live concert. It was compiled mostly from footage that was shot as reference for production discussions and was never meant to be shown publicly. Some of the music and vocals in the film were added from previous recordings, though most were from the live performance. The film was released on October 28, 2009.{{cite web |url=http://www.sonypictures.com/movies/michaeljacksonthisisit/international/ |title=This Is It Worldwide Release Dates |work=[[Sony Pictures|Sony Pictures.com]] |accessdate=September 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090922214515/http://www.sonypictures.com/movies/michaeljacksonthisisit/international/ |archivedate=September 22, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} An accompanying album to the film was also released. Titled ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)|This Is It]]'', the compilation was distributed internationally on October 26, and to North America the following day. The two-disc album features music "inspired from the documentary of the same name".{{cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2009/09/the-michael-jackson-new-musical-onslaught-begins.html |author=Chris Lee |title=The Michael Jackson new-music onslaught begins [Updated] |work=[[The LA Times|TheLATimes.com]] |date=September 23, 2009 |accessdate=September 24, 2009}} Of the album, Sony said, "Disc one will feature the original album masters of some of Michael's biggest hits arranged in the same sequence as they appear in the film" and stated that "the disc ends with two versions of the 'never-released' '[[This Is It (Michael Jackson song)|This Is It]]' [...] This song is featured in the film's closing sequence and includes backing vocals by Michael's brothers, [[The Jacksons]] and Alvin Chea of Take 6."{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/a178845/new-jackson-single-lp-to-be-released.html?imdb |title=New Jackson single, LP to be released |author=Tim Parks |date=September 23, 2009 |work=[[Digital Spy|Digital Spy.com]] |accessdate=September 24, 2009}} Sony added that the second disc will feature previously unreleased versions from Jackson's "catalogue of hits", along with a spoken word [[poem]] entitled "Planet Earth" and a 36-page commemorative booklet with "exclusive photos of Michael from his last rehearsal".{{cite web |url=http://www.theinsider.com/news/2870440_Unreleased_Michael_Jackson_Song_to_be_Revealed|author=The Insider Staff |work=[[The Insider (TV series)|TheInsider.com]] |title=Unreleased Michael Jackson Song to be Revealed |date=September 23, 2009 |accessdate=September 23, 2009}} ==See also== * [[Death of Michael Jackson]] * [[List of works published posthumously]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.michaeljacksonlive.com/ This Is It Official Website] * [http://www.michaeljacksonlive.com/refunds.php/ Official ticket refund website] {{Michael Jackson}} {{DEFAULTSORT:This Is It (concerts)}} [[Category:2009 in London]] [[Category:2010 in London]] [[Category:Cancelled events]] [[Category:Michael Jackson concerts]]

{{Infobox book | | name = Tonto Basin | title_orig = | translator = | image = ZaneGrey TontoBasin.jpg | caption = | author = [[Zane Grey]] | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = [[Western (genre)|Western novel]] | publisher = [[Thompson Gale|Five Star]] (US hardback) &
[[Leisure Books]]
(US paperback) | release_date = 1921 | media_type = Print ([[Hardback]] & [[Paperback]]) | pages = 330 p (hardback) &
321 p (paperback edition) | isbn = 978-0-8439-5602-3 |isbn_note= (paperback edition)
{{ISBN|978-1-59414-050-1}} (hardback edition) | oclc= 63177922 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} ''For the geographical place see [[Tonto Basin]] '''''Tonto Basin''''' is a western novel written by [[Zane Grey]]. ==Origin== ''Tonto Basin'' is the original version of the shorter novel ''[[To the Last Man (Zane Grey)|To The Last Man]]'' (1921). Grey submitted the manuscript of ''Tonto Basin'' to the magazine ''The Country Gentleman,'' which published it in serialization as ''To the Last Man'' from May 28, 1921 through July 30, 1921. This was a much shorter version of the original leaving out much of the [[backstory]] and [[Characterisation|character development]]. This shorter version was published as a [[book]] by [[Harper Brothers]] in 1921. ==Plot introduction== A story of a feud between two families, the evil it causes, and the power of love to transcend all. ==Plot summary== The story begins with 24-year-old Jean Isbel in the last stages of a multi-week trip from Oregon to the frontier in Arizona where his family had moved four years earlier to start a cattle ranch. As he nears his destination he meets a woman in the woods, and falls in love at first sight. As they part they learn that they are mortal enemies. She is Ellen Jorth, and her family is locked in a deadly feud with his. Jean dreads the part his father, Gaston, wants him to play in the feud. He can’t get Ellen out of his mind. They meet again and his words awake in her doubt and fear that her father, Lee Jorth, is not an honorable man but in fact a horse thief and cattle rustler. As events unfold her fears are proved true. Through thick and thin Jean Isbel defends Ellen’s honor and believes the best of her. The feud erupts into fatal gun battles, first at the Isbel ranch house, and then at the general store in the nearby town. Most of the Isbel and Jorth clans are killed, with several of their allies. The remnant of the Jorths flee with Ellen in tow to a hide-out hidden in a deep box cañon. Jean and his allies track them and there is a deadly gun battle in the woods nearby. Ellen is forced by one of the three remaining Jorth allies to flee once again. During their flight their horse is shot out from under them. Ellen now on foot meets one of the dying Isbels and finally learns the certain truth that her father, family, and their allies were horse thieves and cattle rustlers as she feared. When she finally makes her way back to the hide-out, she arrives just after Jean has been forced to take refuge in the loft, unknown to her. One of the two remaining rustlers attacks her with rape in mind but is interrupted by the arrival of the other rustler. Ellen discovers Jean during this interruption. When the rustler returns a few minutes later, Ellen is forced to kill him to protect herself and Jean. A minute later Jean kills the last rustler. The story ends with Jean and Ellen declaring their love for each other. ==Themes== The book is concerned with the destruction deadly violence wreaks on those family members who survive. Grey writes about the intense concern Jean feels for the impact the violence will have on the wives and children whose husbands and fathers will die in the feud. The feud is caused by a love triangle between Gaston Isbel, Lee Jorth, and Ellen the woman both love, and the mother of Ellen Jorth. The story explores how love, betrayal, and jealousy can engender a hate which leads two men to destroy their families, without a thought to the pain and suffering of those relatives who will be left to bury the dead. Ellen grows from a naïve girl to a woman of understanding under the severe trial of the events which overtake her. She begins to examine critically her own behavior with wisdom and insight. She grows and matures emotionally and psychologically, becoming aware that her father whom she had supported with unquestioning trust, is in fact a scoundrel, a thief, and a thoroughly dishonorable rogue. At the end she acts decisively and fatally to protect herself, her virtue, and the man she loves. ==Characters in "To the Last Man"== * Jean Isbel – the hero, a person of mixed race, being part [[Nez Perce tribe|Nez Perce]] * Gaston Isbel – Jean's father, and the head of the Isbel faction. * Guy Isble – Jean's oldest brother. * Bill Isble – Jean's older brother. * Ann Isble – Jean's sister. * Andrew Colmor – Ann's fiancé. * Jim Blaisdell – Gaston's good friend and supporter. * Blue – member of the Isbel faction. * Lee Jorth – the head of the Jorth faction. * Ellen Jorth – Lee's daughter. * Tad Jorth – Lee's brother, Ellen's uncle. * Jackson Jorth – Lee's brother, Ellen's uncle. * Jim Colter – member of the Jorth faction. * Springer – member of the Jorth faction. * Sommers – member of the Jorth faction. * Rock Wells – member of the Jorth faction. * Colter – member of the Jorth faction. * Simm Bruce – member of the Jorth faction. * Ben Greaves – owner of the General Store. * John Sprague – Ellen's confidante and only friend. ==Publication== In the early 1990s, [[Jon Tuska]], was researching the [[filmography]] of Zane Grey. During this research he discovered that ''[[Last of the Duanes (novel)|Last of the Duanes]]'' and ''[[Rangers of the Lone Star]]'' were much altered from the [[holograph]] found "in the bottom drawer of a file cabinet in the Zane Grey, Inc. room where it had survived for eighty years.".Grey, Zane: "Tonto Basin", (quote from the ''Foreword'' by Jon Tuska) page 8. Five Star, 2004. {{ISBN|978-1-59414-050-1}} This caused him to request that they "tell me of any other manuscripts...that had met a similar fate."Grey, Zane: "Tonto Basin", (quote from the ''Foreword'' by Jon Tuska) page 9. Five Star, 2004. {{ISBN|978-1-59414-050-1}} The result was the discovery of the complete holographic [[manuscript]] of the novel ''[[To the Last Man (Zane Grey)|To the Last Man]]''. A comparison of the holograph with ''To the Last Man'' revealed that the holograph was much longer, and contained detail which altered the meaning of the story. The complete uncut version was published in 2004. ==See also== {{portal|Novels}} *''[[To the Last Man (1933 film)|To the Last Man]]'' is a 1933 [[Henry Hathaway]] film based on the [[Zane Grey]] novel starring [[Randolph Scott]], [[Esther Ralston]], [[Buster Crabbe]], [[Barton MacLane]], [[Noah Beery]], [[Shirley Temple]], and [[Eugenie Besserer]]. * [[Frederick Russell Burnham]] participated on the losing side in the real-life [[Pleasant Valley War|Tonto Basin feud]] and narrowly escaped alive. After the feud, he went home to [[California]] and left for [[Africa]] only a few years later.{{cite book | last =Burnham | first =Frederick Russell | authorlink =Frederick Russell Burnham | coauthors = | title =Scouting on Two Continents | publisher =Doubleday, Page and Co | year =1926 | location = New York | pages = Chapters 3 & 4| url = | doi = | id = ASIN B000F1UKOA }}{{cite journal| author =R. R. Money|date=April 1962 | title=Tonto Basin Feud | journal=[[Blackwood's Magazine]]| volume=291| issue=| issn=0006-436X }} * Tonto Basin Outlaws (1941) - A film based very loosely on the Tonto Basin feud. These cowboys are out to stop a cattle-rustling scandal soon after they enlist with [[Teddy Roosevelt]]'s [[Rough Riders]].{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0034300/ |title=Tonto Basin Outlaws (1941)|accessdate=2007-07-07 |work=Internet Movie Database}} In the real-life feud, one man did go on to join the Rough Riders. * [[Pleasant Valley War]] ==Footnotes== {{Reflist}} [[Category:1921 American novels]] [[Category:Western (genre) novels]] [[Category:Novels by Zane Grey]] [[Category:Novels set in Arizona]] [[Category:Works based on actual events]]

[[File:Lockerbie disaster memorial.jpg|right|thumb|300px|A memorial is often established to remember lives lost in a tragedy such as the [[Lockerbie air disaster]]]] A '''tragedy''' is an event of great loss, usually of human life. Such an event is said to be ''tragic''. Traditionally the event would require "some element of moral failure, some flaw in character, or some extraordinary combination of elements"<ref>http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19920405&slug=1484688</ref> to be tragic.
Not all death is considered a tragedy. Rather it is a precise set of symptoms surrounding the loss that define it as such.<ref>{{cite book |title=Crisis Intervention Training for Disaster Workers: An Introduction |last=Doherty |first=George W. |authorlink= |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=12 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> There are a variety of factors that define a death as ''tragic''.
An event in which a massive number of deaths occur may be seen as a tragedy. This can be re-enforced by media attention or other public outcry.<ref name=Lattanzi1>{{cite book |title=Coping with public tragedy |last=Lattanzi-Licht |first=Marcia E. |authorlink= |author2=Kenneth J. Doka |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=1 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
A tragedy does not necessarily involve [[massacre|massive death]]. The death of a single person, e.g., a public figure or a child, may be seen as a tragedy.<ref name=Lattanzi1/> The person need not necessarily have been [[celebrity|famous]] before death.
==Factors that make death a tragedy== Generally, the label of "tragedy" is given to an event based on public perception.<ref>{{cite book |title=Coping with public tragedy |last=Lattanzi-Licht |first=Marcia E. |authorlink= |author2=Kenneth J. Doka |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=11 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> There are a number of factors that can make a death be considered a tragedy.
===Scope=== The scope of an event can affect the public view, and make it appear tragic. This can be the case whether the death toll is high, or if a single, unexpected death occurs in a well-beloved person.<ref>{{cite book |title=Coping with public tragedy |last=Lattanzi-Licht |first=Marcia E. |authorlink= |author2=Kenneth J. Doka |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=5 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
The degree of attachment in the public eye may also impact whether or not the event is publicly labeled as a tragedy. For example, the unexpected death of a [[University-preparatory school|preparatory school]] student that receives heavy media attention may be seen as more tragic than that of a [[recidivism|recidivist]] prisoner who is beaten to death by fellow inmates.<ref name=Lattanzi1 />
===Prematurity=== A death may be viewed as a tragedy when it is premature in nature. An old person dying of old age is an expectation, but the death of a child or of a young, healthy adult that is not expected by others can be viewed as tragic.<ref name=Lattanzi1/>
===Publicity=== [[Publicity]] is a factor in making the public view an event as a tragedy. With publicity of a large number of deaths or even a single death, this plays on the emotions of the general public, and thereby impacts perception.<ref>{{cite book |title=Coping with public tragedy |last=Lattanzi-Licht |first=Marcia E. |authorlink= |author2=Kenneth J. Doka |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=3 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
The range of coverage affects the number of people in whose eyes the event is viewed as tragic. While local coverage may garner sympathy from those in the hometown of the deceased, international coverage may lead the whole world to mourn.<ref>{{cite book |title=Coping with public tragedy |last=Lattanzi-Licht |first=Marcia E. |authorlink= |author2=Kenneth J. Doka |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=9 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
===Consequences=== The resulting consequences from one or more deaths can be seen as a tragedy. For example, if a large number of persons are killed in a terrorist attack, not only is life lost, but others may lose their sense of security, and this impacts the lives of others in other ways.<ref>{{cite book |title=Coping with public tragedy |last=Lattanzi-Licht |first=Marcia E. |authorlink= |author2=Kenneth J. Doka |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=8 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
===Lasting effects=== The long-term effects of an event can render it as tragic. Tragedies often have effects that shape those affected, and are remembered even long after, as they clearly impact the future for those involved. They may also be commemorated on anniversaries or whenever they otherwise come to mind.<ref>Disaster Spiritual Care: Practical Clergy Responses to Community, Regional; by Stephen B. Roberts, Willard W. C. Ashley; {{ISBN|978-1-59473-240-9}}; page 67</ref> A public tragedy often leads to measures being taken to prevent similar tragic events in the future.<ref>{{cite book |title=Disaster Spiritual Care: Practical Clergy Responses to Community, Regional, and National Tragedy |last=Roberts |first=Stephen B. |authorlink= |author2=Willard W. C. Ashley |publisher= |location= |isbn=978-1-59473-240-9 |page=86 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
==Dealing with tragedy== There are various ways tragedy can affect people.
The typical reaction to tragedy is heavy [[grief]], followed by a slow recovery. Common feelings following a tragedy include [[sadness]], [[depression (mood)|depression]], [[crying]], [[blame]], and [[guilt (emotion)|guilt]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Tragedy: A psychiatrist offers ways to deal with trauma and grief |author=Alvin F. Poussaint, M.D. |newspaper=Ebony Magazine |date=February 1977 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AM4DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA94&dq=coping+with+tragedy&hl=en&ei=jUT4TIfBFIWClAe0rvGgAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=coping%20with%20tragedy&f=false |accessdate=}} </ref> Some people wonder what they did to deserve such suffering.<ref>{{cite book |title=Coping with Tragedy |last=Ramsey |first=Tara |authorlink= |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=33 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
For some, their [[religion|faith]] may be a source of comfort in the wake of tragedy.<ref>{{cite book |title=Faith in the Fast Lane |last=Owens |first=Ken |authorlink= |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=106 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Disaster]] *[[Collective trauma]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Grief]] [[Category:Events]]
